urn:contentItem:5G51-7331-JBKD-44H5-00000-00Terror fight pits feds against tech giants2015-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisNEWSLocalPg. 7Terror fight pits feds against tech giantsKIMBERLY ATKINS

WASHINGTON - The thwarted terror plot against Boston police has inflamed the battle between federal law enforcement authorities who want more social media surveillance tools to fight homeland terrorists and tech giants like Apple and Google who claim those measures would put privacy and data security at risk.

And President Obama is stuck in the middle.

Yesterday, officials from the FBI and the Department of Homeland Security said the alleged plot by Usaamah Rahim to kill Boston police officers exemplifies the increasing threat posed by radicalized terrorists on American soil.

'We know that ISIL has put out a message to attack the West, specifically law enforcement,' Michael Steinbach, assistant director of the FBI's counterterrorism division, told members of the House Homeland Security Committee.

While Steinbach praised the work of the Boston Joint Terrorism Task Force in monitoring Rahim and moving quickly to stop an imminent threat, he said intelligence and law enforcement officials are often stymied by terror suspects' use of encrypted Internet and text messaging. Even if they can intercept a message, the content remains a mystery.

'There are 200-plus social media companies. Some of these companies build their business model around end-to-end encryption,' Steinbach said. And that, he said, is what terror groups count on.

Following the congressional fight over the USA Freedom Act and federal access to cellphone metadata, the debate has switched to encryption, covered by other laws and regulations.

The FBI's push to amend federal law to give federal officials the keys to social media companies' encryption systems comes as the tech industry has stepped up its lobbying against such measures. Just last month, a coalition of advocacy groups, companies and trade organizations wrote a letter to President Obama warning him that the FBI's request would weaken cybersecurity and privacy rights.

'The administration faces a critical choice: will it adopt policies that foster a global digital ecosystem that is more secure, or less?' stated the letter, signed by groups including the ACLU, Apple and Facebook.

So far, Obama has hedged. At a cybersecurity summit earlier this year, he called for a 'pubic conversation' on the issue.

While he acknowledged at the summit that 'the first time that attack takes place in which it turns out that we had a lead and we couldn't follow up on it, the public's going to demand answers,' in an interview later for the website Re/code, Obama said he leans 'further in the direction of strong encryption than some do inside of law enforcement.'

But while recent homegrown plots in Boston and Texas were averted, the threat of more will only intensify the debate as lawmakers feel pressure to stay a step ahead of other lone wolves before they strike at police.

'We're doing a good job swatting mosquitos,' said U.S. Rep. Bill Keating (D-Bourne), 'but we are not drying up the swamp as much as we can.'

MIDDLE MAN: President Obama is caught in the middle between federal law enforcement, which wants more social media tools to fight terror, and big tech companies, which cite the need for cybersecurity.

PRIVATE VIEWING: Boston police headquarters, above, was where community leaders were shown the video of the shooting of terror suspect Usaamah Rahim.

AP FILE PHOTO

Staff Photo by Matt Stone

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PVT-R3W1-JB20-G3FG-00000-00Terrorist Enemy Combatant; Chaffetz: Deport The Family; Awaiting Terror Update; Federal Terror Charges2017-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisRISK & REWARD5:00 PM ESTJames Mitchell, Steve RogersNEWSFinancial110101cb.233Terrorist Enemy Combatant; Chaffetz: Deport The Family; Awaiting Terror Update; Federal Terror ChargesCheryl Casone

MELISSA FRANCIS, HOST, FOX NEWS: Risk & Reward starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Shots fired.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You know, we got -- we got multiple casualties. There's a mass casualty situation here.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Did you call 911?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: My God. My God. OK. I need an ambulance right here.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I see, you know, a truck a few more blocks down going down the bike path.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This vehicle method by ISIS is something that ISIS is now using as a routine vector for attacks. We have to look at every aspect of every individual to make sure that we're not importing Europe's terror problems.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I've seen a couple of bodies lying right there on the bike path.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It appears that Mr. Saipov had been planning this for a number of weeks; he did this in the name of ISIS.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You don't play bingo and give the guy a green card.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Our nation as a whole we have to get tougher, we have to get much smarter. We have to get much less politically collect.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHERYL CASONE, HOST, FOX NEWS: And new details emerging about yesterday's terror attack, the worst attack in New York City since 9/11, Sayfullo Saipov the 29-year-old Uzbek immigrant, who mowed down more than a dozen innocent pedestrian and bikers, with a pickup truck in the name of ISIS, was planning the attack for weeks.

Investigators now combing through his home in New Jersey, we've got the details coming out.

And we've got the latest on tax reform, House republicans now postponing the release of their tax bill by one day to tomorrow. But new details on how it may affect your wallet are leaking out. And we've got them.

Also, breaking news, the White House has just notified Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell. That President Trump intends to nominate him as next chairman of the Central Bank.

Grover Norquist is here to weigh in on that breaking news. Plus, big tech companies like Facebook and Tesla just releasing earnings after the bell. Also those Russia-back Facebook ads have just been released, and they look like they support Bernie Sanders. We're going to go through them for you.

Retired lieutenant General Tom McInerney, Americans for Tax Reform's Grover Norquist, Muslim Reform Movement Asra Nomani, and former FBI counterterrorism task force member Steve Roger is here all here all speaking out tonight.

And welcome, to Risk & Reward. I'm Cheryl Casone.

Well, the market shaken up, our latest terror attack in the city. The Dow, the S&P, and the NASDAQ, hitting intraday all-time highs today. Tech heavyweights Apple, Facebook, and Alibaba hitting record highs as well, driving the NASDAQ higher.

U.S. companies reporting they've added most workers in seven months, consumer confidence also hitting its highest level since December of 2000.

And this just in, the breaking news, the president reportedly is going to tap Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell to be the next chairman of the Federal Reserve. All of this as a horrific terror attack hits New York City.

Homeland Security Chairman Michael McCaul saying the deadly truck attack is the 9th vehicle assault used by ISIS.

President Trump responding, saying "Our diversity visa program is at fault."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

Trump: What we are demanding is merit-based immigration. We want people that are going to help our country, we want people that are going to keep our country safe. We don't want lotteries.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: President Trump starting the process of ending the program that the suspect allegedly use to legally enter the U.S. that use lottery toward visa instead of judging people on their merit.

Here with the latest on the terror attack, our own Connell McShane, he's joining us now from the scene. A very busy day down there today, Connell. Hello.

CONNELL MCSHANE, CORRESPONDENT, FOX BUSINESS: It is indeed, Cheryl. And we've just learned some new information in the last few minute from Justice Department officials to tell us that the suspected terrorist in yesterday's attack, Sayfullo Saipov will be making a court appearance and will be making that court appearance tonight. That's important for a couple of reasons which we'll get into a moment.

But first to the investigation happening here in New York and across the river in New Jersey, the newest video shots just moments ago, it shows the vehicle that was used in this attack that killed eight being driven away from the scene, it had been here throughout the day.

But in video you see it under the tarp. The New York City Police Department vehicle being driven away. Earlier today our cameras caught that vehicle on West Street, it was still there. The white Home Depot-rented flatbed truck with both doors at the time still open, you can see the damage that was done when it collided with a school bus that ended this attack.

Two adults and two children injured in that particular collision, eight killed overall. And a police officer came out and shot that suspected terrorist. Now only that he survived, but as he say he will be appear in in court.

We also learned some about his planning from New York City officials. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN MILLER, DEPUTY COMMISSIONER, NEW YORK POLICE DEPARTMENT: Based on the investigation overnight, it appears that Mr. Saipov had been planning this for a number of weeks, he did this in the name of ISIS. And along with the other items recovered at the scene was some notes that further indicate that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Yes, notes that were written in Arabic, and certainly left clear indications that this was a terrorist attack inspired by ISIS, officials say. They have taken their investigation over to Paterson, New Jersey, as well where this man most recently lived and he's thought to have attended a mosque in that area, it's not very far from where he lived that he rented that truck yesterday.

At about an hour or later he was here in Lower Manhattan carrying out this attack.

Now, Cheryl, to get back to where we started here, we've learned in the last few minutes that he'll make a court appearance tonight. As I said that is important for a couple of different reasons. Number one, I guess it speaks to his wellbeing to some degree, we were told he underwent what is described to us as minor surgery after being shot by that police officer.

So, from this official that we spoke to at the court house, apparently he's well enough to be in court, but it also tells us more importantly that he will go through the civilian criminal justice system, rather than being sent as some speculated to Guantanamo Bay. That will not happen if he appears in court as expected to tonight.

So, with that, back to you.

CASONE: Not an enemy combatant. Connell, that's very interesting. And also we're learning that there is going to be a press conference from the southern district of New York, the United States Attorney General, so we hopefully get some more details about the charges and exactly what they're going to look like.

Connell McShane, thank you for that live report on the scene. A busy day, of course down in Lower Manhattan.

Well, for more on the New York terror suspect entering U.S., under the diversity visa program that President Trump wants to end since it allows people it's based on a lottery, instead of merit.

Well, former Trump foreign policy adviser Sebastian Gorka tell Fox Newsthat political correctness it going to get us killed. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEBASTIAN GORKA, FORMER TRUMP FOREIGN POLICY ADVISOR: Look at Australia, look at New Zealand, they have incredibly stringent immigration requirements, it's based upon education, it's based upon skill set, there's a whole slew of yardsticks you have to meet. And if don't meet them you don't get to come in, you don't play bingo and give the guy a green card, political correctness can get people killed.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: All right. Former Air Force assistant vice chief of staff retired lieutenant general Tom McInerney joins me now. General, it's good to have you here.

THOMAS MCINERNEY, RETIRED UNITED STATES AIR FORCE: Thanks for having me, Cheryl.

CASONE: You know, Congress has tried to end the diversity visa lottery program five times since 2007. Do you agree with the president, do you think that program is dangerous, and should be at least reevaluated?

MCINERNEY: Absolutely, Cheryl. There is no reason why we need a diversity visa program. This is an example of what's happened, and how many other potential terrorist have we brought in with this program if you look at the nations there. We don't need that kind of diversity.

And so, I think it's extremely important that the president get rid of this program. Even if it's by an executive order if in fact he could do that. But we need to get rid of it as quickly as possible.

CASONE: Well, if that is possible I guess will be the next kind of shoe to drop on this. But you know, this suspect applied for that program back in 2008, he was granted a diverse visa two years later.

I mean, this though, we should point out to be clear is the fourth assailant from Uzbekistan to launch an attack in less a year, that's according to several reports. I mean, retired CIA officer Gary Berntsen told Fox the country is well-known terrorist hotbed and we let him in. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GARY BERNTSEN, FORMER CIA OFFICER: Uzbekistan in particular, has a history of Jihadism. There is an organization that was founded years ago called the IMU, the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan. There is a place in Uzbekistan called the Ferghana Valley where Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan and I think Kazakhstan all meet together. Excuse me, Kazakhstan all meet together.

But that is a group of bandit terrorists they were married to Taliban, we fought them before, a lot of these people have been inside Afghanistan. And the fact that we would have a diversity program open to allow people to come in is just, it's insane.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: And especially from Uzbekistan. That is the point here. According to the international crisis group between 2,000 and 4,000 militants from Central Asia may have signed up for ISIS. And Uzbek nationals or ethnic Uzbeks from neighboring states make up the largest single group of ISIS supporters among Central Asians. I mean, should there be more protections more monitoring of this country?

MCINERNEY: Absolutely, Cheryl. I mean, it's insane what we are doing for diversity. The fact is this, when you listen to Governor Cuomo and the mayor, they do not understand what they talk about lone wolves. There is no such thing as a lone wolf.

They are soldiers of Allah. They are soldiers of Islam, they are always connected to it in the ideology. People who talk about lone wolves are really do not understand what the ideology we are facing. And it's extremely important that we do that and incumbent upon us to put the responsibility back on the Muslims to fix this. Infidels can't fix this ideology problem.

CASONE: Yes. That lone wolf statement from Governor Cuomo last night has really been hotly debated today. And we're going to talk about that later on in the show.

General, thank you for being here tonight. I really appreciate your perspective on all of this.

MCINERNEY: Thanks, Cheryl.

CASONE: Well, House republicans postponing the roll out of their tax reform bill too tomorrow. It was supposed to be this morning remember, saying that they need to finalize a few key details.

President Trump talking about the much anticipated release. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The House is doing very well. They've taken an extra few hours, which will go in tomorrow, I think tomorrow and they'll be announcing and I'll probably be standing with them, we're leaving as you know, Asia. We're leaving on Friday morning, so I'll be standing with them, sometime tomorrow. We'll be announcing massive tax cuts and reform.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Like the president is suggesting calling the tax bill the cut, cut act, no word on whether that's going to be accepted by the Hill, maybe becoming a special name.

But the president reportedly tapping Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell as the next Fed chairman, that is the breaking news.

Grover Norquist, Americans for Tax Reform president is with me now. And I want to start with that one. Well, OK, let's put Jerome on the sideline because we kind of expected that. But as far as taxes tomorrow, I mean, what do you make of this whole one day delay? We're going to work on the details. Haven't they had seven years to work on the details, Grover?

GROVER NORQUIST, PRESIDENT, AMERICANS FOR TAX REFORM: Well, they've got a very nice outline which is extremely helpful, they are staying within it. What you are doing now is kind of negotiation and coming to an agreement that otherwise might be happening at the committee level or on floor of the House or on a joint Senate house conference.

The fact that they are doing it now, as they did with the budget, remember that that budget could have taken three weeks, instead they sat down, they worked it out. The Senate accepted the House amendments; the House accepted the Senate bill, boom, done in two days. Very impressive, save this two and a half, maybe three weeks on the agenda.

So, to take the day now and negotiate some of the two or three things that are being worked on rather than doing that over a couple of weeks I think it's a good use of time. And it's helpful.

CASONE: Grover, I just have to say really quick that there are so many, you know, bones of contention, if you will, on this thing from the state and local deduction to what's happening with the estate tax, leaving that 39.6 percent top tier rate on this hiring Americans.

I mean, there just seems -- it seems to me again, they were coming out and seeing more divisive pieces of tax reform. And doesn't that put getting this thing through in jeopardy, aka, healthcare.

NORQUIST: OK. No, because the things that used to be divisive are now all agreed to. The idea of a 20 percent corporate rate, originally the House was at 25, Trump came in said 15, this is a year ago, a year and a quarter ago. And the House moved down to 20. And Trump came up from 15. They agreed on 20.

You got full and immediate business expensing, but it's difficult to do it permanently, so do you it for five years.

CASONE: Right.

NORQUIST: These are now settled questions, we're debating other much smaller questions than those right there. So, I think that's progress. We do need to get all the stuff down, no reason to wait till December.

CASONE: OK. Grover, really quick. I 've got five seconds. Jerome Powell, do you like the pick.

NORQUIST: Yes, good pick.

CASONE: I figured that much. Question is over. Grover...

(CROSSTALK)

NORQUIST: Can we call him Jerry, though.

CASONE: All right. Well, maybe. I don't know if we're allowed to do that. We'll see. Grover Norquist, thanks, Grover. It's good to have you on.

NORQUIST: You got it.

CASONE: All right. Well, social media company Facebook just coming out with earnings after the bell, they did beat on revenue by, yes, a billion dollars. Take a look, the stock is trading up slightly after hours. Definitely a stock to watch tomorrow.

Well, yes, the White House has notified Federal Reserve Governor Jerome J. Powell, I'm not calling him Jerry, Grover. That President Trump intends to nominate him as the next chairman of the Central Bank.

Adam Shapiro is here with the latest. All right. So, Grover likes him, Adam.

ADAM SHAPIRO, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: Well, the president likes it, that's what matters. And Congress most likely will like it as well. Because look, this is a man who is a lifelong republican, who worked at the Treasury Department from roughly 1990 to 93, he was undersecretary at treasury and investigating domestic finance.

You might remember Solomon brothers, he was involved in some investigation of Solomon brothers, as well an investigation of what was this, yes, Solomon. But he also went to bankers trust, he worked for the Carlyle Group at one point, and then he comes back into you might say the government when Barack Obama the president, the democrat nominated him to join the board of governors, he took office with the Federal Reserve in 2012.

So we actually spoke with Governor Powell back at Jackson hall in August about the potential that he might become the next Fed chair. I think we have the sound bite ready in which he responded to what would you do if the president called you. And here's what he said.

We don't have the sound bite ready, but what he essentially said is that "This is a job that requires deep knowledge of Federal Reserve operations, I think it helps to have knowledge of the economic issues that we face."

Now he does understand the economic issues, some people say he is kind of neutral on, for instance, Dodd-Frank regulation, but says we can do that more efficiently. He wrote a paper and deliver a speech about six months ago, calling for Congress to reform Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, he says that issue has not been resolved.

Some people refer to him somewhat as a dove. He's probably more neutral when it comes to monetary policy, expect more of the same, but perhaps with a few more papers from Governor Powell.

CASONE: It seems like a safer pick. I think that's kind of how many characterize him, which is OK. I mean, we don't need controversy at the Fed. That's for sure.

SHAPIRO: Well, he has real world experience, again, he was at Carlyle Group, he was I think at Bankers Trust at one point. But the other issue that this doesn't get a talk a lot about. But back during the financial cliff several years ago, he was actually, he wasn't in government service at that point, remember he's been in treasury.

He was going up to Capitol Hill talking to different lawmaker about why that would be a horrible thing to allow the United States to miss its debt payment.

CASONE: Interesting.

SHAPIRO: So this is not only a man who has real world experience in finance, the politics as well.

CASONE: And you know him, Adam Shapiro, live in Washington. Adam, thank you.

All right. Well, OK, those Russia-funded Facebook ads that have been released by the House intelligence committee, they seem to back Bernie Sanders. What is up with that? We're going to show those to you. We just got them a little bit later in the show.

But first this, more details coming out about the New York City terrorist as the FBI is now seeking information on a second person in relation to the New York attack, details next.

CASONE: All right. Electric carmaker Tesla reporting earnings just moments ago, shocking investors with a bigger loss than expected. Now they are slashing production of the model X and the model S, that's not really good. Shares is falling about 3 percent, it's falling another 3 percent after the bell so it's definitely a stock to watch tomorrow morning when trading opens up once again.

Also getting breaking new. Just in, the FBI we're just being told are seeking a second person Mukhammadzoir Kadirov in relation to the attack in New York City yesterday.

And here is what we know right now. They are describing this person, brown eyes, a white male, born November 5, 1984. He's about 39 years old and he's from Uzbekistan. Remember, the suspect, the current suspect also is from Uzbekistan. The second individual that they are looking for right now also from Uzbekistan.

If you see this person if you recognize this person, you are told to contact the FBI right away especially if you are in the New York area.

I wanted to get that breaking news, they are seeking a second person in connection with the terror attack in New York City yesterday.

Now all of this is happening as President Trump wants to step up extreme vetting. But New York democratic Congressman Jerrold Nadler says there is no way that the U.S. can improve this process. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JERROLD NADLER, (D) UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: No amount of extreme vetting is going to stop that, the president is usually as usual, went off halfcocked out without for the facts. If you're talking about a refugee, someone is going to come here, they get extreme vetting. It takes about two years to go through the vetting process in which the American intelligence agencies (Inaudible) are looking at people. I don't know how you could improve that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: All right. But retired lieutenant Colonel Tony Shaffer said our vetting is not good enough.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TONY SHAFFER, FORMER CIA INTELLIGENCE OFFICER: We didn't vet the guy beforehand, Brian, I mean, his name himself is sword of Allah, that's the clue. The sword of Allah, so that's not like Joe, and I think that was a clue to where he came from.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: All right. Joining me now, the author of "Standing Alone: An American Woman Struggle for the Soul of Islam" and co-author of the Muslim Reform Movement, Asra Nomani. Asra, it's great to have you here, so much to discuss with this.

You know, a lot of liberal are arguing that extreme vetting it's just not going to help. Attackers are radicalized after they're admitted into the United States. What do you say?

ASRA NOMANI, CO-FOUNDER, MUSLIM REFORM MOVEMENT: Well, I do believe that we need to do more vetting, we have to do vetting not only of human beings but we have to do vetting of the ideas that are crossing into America's borders.

The real issue that concerns me as a liberal is that too many people on the left, and inside of our Democratic Party are refusing to acknowledge the ideological problem that is the underlying issue behind this Manhattan attack.

We had unfortunately this afternoon the former journalist and interviewer of Osama Bin Laden stepping forward to speak for the NYPD. And saying that this attack had nothing to do with Islam. We have Muslim activists who are trying to claim that you are Islamophobic if you talk about Islamic extremism.

The real issue is that we're not vetting our ideas, and we're not saying Islamic supremacy and Islamic radicalism are not OK in this world, and that's the heart of what we need to tackle as a country. And unfortunately, what I see on that part is a lot of cowardice.

CASONE: Well, and it means being politically incorrect, which is something that the country, I mean, we've gone the opposite direct, especially under the previous administration.

So, what about the vetting process, if they do enhance vetting, if they really step this up as President Trump has discussed, do you think that that would help stop these ISIS-inspired attacks in United States.

NOMANI: I don't think they will stop it honestly, because these ideas are crossing borders that are porous. We have to have increased vetting because we are in fact not doing enough to stop radicalization from coming in to this country.

And the idea that we can top through human being this threat is one that we shouldn't be naive about. We have to continue to put pressure on governments like Saudi Arabia and Qatar so that they shut down the mosques and the propaganda channels that are putting out the kind of ideology that makes a man think that it's Islamic and legal and religious to then plow people on the streets of Manhattan and then declare allahu akbar. God is great.

CASONE: Yes. It's amazing, still I think kind of surreal what happened yesterday here in New York.

And I do want to switch gears. So Fox is reporting that mosque that the terrorist attended was on MYPD watch list for years. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROB SCHMITT, ANCHOR, FOX NEWS: The Mosque right behind me here, the Omar mosque we're actually outside of Sayfullo Saipov's mosque and also his residents because he lived right behind this mosque right back over here. The Omar mosque right behind me, has been on the NYPD's radar even though we're in New Jersey, been on the New York City Police Department's radar since 2005. They've been keeping an eye on this mosque.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: What do you make of that? That they've been watching that mosque for years.

NOMANI: You know, it's really tragic to me. I came to this country as a 4- year-old, and I moved, I first lived in New Jersey. That's where my father was sending Rutgers University. My father fought so that Saudi influence would not come to mosque here in America. But we have been penetrated by dangerous ideologies.

CASONE: Yes.

NOMANI: And it only took me two seconds looking at the Facebook page of that mosque to know that it is intolerant.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: It is so frightening. Asra, it's so frightening. Thank you so much for being here tonight, so much more to talk with you. We will be right back.

CASONE: OK. Breaking news, we want to let you know you're looking right now at live pictures here in New York, a press conference is about to begin to announce federal terrorism charges against Sayfullo Saipov, related to yesterday's deadly attack in lower Manhattan.

We are monitoring the podium right now. We are expecting to see Joon Kim, acting United States Attorney for southern district of New York, as well as William Sweeney, the assistant director in-charge and James O'Neill. We are told is going to be there as well.

Of course he is the police commissioner of the city of New York. So we expect to see all of them out there in just the next few moments. We will take you there live when that press conference starts, and actually, here we go. They are coming out right once again, I believe this is, if we're going to start with -- let's listen in.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Everybody ready?

RYAN NASH, POLICE OFFICER, NYPD: Hello, thank you for coming. I am Officer Ryan Nash. I appreciate the public recognition of the actions of myself and my fellow officers yesterday, although I feel that we were just doing our job like thousands of officers do every day, I understand the importance of yesterday's events.

And role we played, and I am grateful for the recognition we have received. I just want to thank my family and friends for their support and all the responding officers who assisted me. However, due to the nature of the pending criminal case, I cannot make any further public statements about the incident at this time, thank you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you, guys.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: OK, so that was interesting, that was Ryan Nash. That is the NYPD, the hero officer. He has been called today here in New York City, that actually was the first person to come upon the suspect here in New York.

Ryan Nash coming out and saying he couldn't say much more but just really being appreciative of the fact that there has been such an outpouring of him and again, he has been called a hero. He is the one that first apprehended and shot the suspect here in New York.

So again, we weren't exactly sure how that was going to go down but we are again waiting for that press conference, but we had guidance that it's going to start in next 10 minutes or so. When the full press conference starts with FBI, with the police commissioner, and with the United States district attorney of New York, we are going to take you back.

We're going to get the formal charges, but again, these aren't going to be criminal charges. Many had wanted these charges to be basically federal terrorism charges, these are going to be criminal terrorism charges, and there is a difference here and how -- he going to go through the criminal court system basically.

All right, while we're waiting for that press conference to begin, moving on to some other things that we've been following for you, in this story, the White House saying today that it considers the New York terrorist is enemy combatant, OK?

That's why we're just talking about what the charges and how they are different. President Trump said, basically, that he would like to see this prisoner, basically, this attacker, go to Guantanamo Bay. That is military detention center there in Cuba while he awaits trial. Well, Senator Lindsey Graham agreed with that, saying that terrorist doesn't deserve U.S. criminal protection. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: The last thing I want this guy to hear tonight, is you have the right to a lawyer, the last thing he should hear is his Miranda rights, I have been a military lawyer for 33 years.

There is enough evidence to believe that he qualifies as an enemy combatant on the law of law. He can be held by intelligence community, as long as necessary to find out, did he act alone and was he part of a bigger plot.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: OK, I wanted to follow-up with that sound bite. Obviously there is a lot of talk about the types of charges and where this court -- this trial is going to be held, all of that we're waiting to get more details. We're waiting on that breaking news. We're going to take a quick commercial break, Risk and Reward will be right back, stay with us.

CASONE: We continue to follow the story of the terror attack here in New York City yesterday. Right now, I'm going to bring in the man who interrogated 9/11 mastermind, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed. And his interrogation author James Mitchell. James, it's great to have you here. There are so many questions about this seems to be handled by authorities.

JAMES MITCHELL, FORMER MEMBER, UNITED STATES AIR FORCE: OK, do you have one?

CASONE: Yes, I do have a question. The NYPD referred to Sayfullo Saipov as a criminal, but the White House thinks that he should be considered as enemy combatant. I'm curious what you think about that.

MITCHELL: I think he should be considered an illegal enemy combatant, not an enemy combatant. An illegal enemy combatant is a person who doesn't fight a standing army, doesn't wear a uniform and breaks the international laws of war.

And under those circumstances, are not subject to the Geneva Convention, unless we decide that he is. So I would -- I would echo what President Trump said, and I think what Senator Graham said, we should be interested in interrogating that guy to find out, since we know that he is not there by himself.

And that he came here probably already radicalized and then honed it while here, he brought those bad ideas with him, we should figure out who he brought with him because he had a chain of people that he allowed -- they allowed him to bring to United States.

We should figure out which of those folks are radicalized. We should figure out what his network is, who has been providing support, who he got radicalized and we should treat him like an enemy combatant.

CASONE: Well, but this look like that, really going to happen here. This is going to go -- I mean, we're waiting on this press conference by the United States attorney general and police commissioner. It looks like he is going through the regular court system, that means a lawyer, James. I mean, that's what were looking at here. Do you think this is the right...

MITCHELL: Well, he is probable -- well, he is probably already been Mirandized, right? Because he was arrest a New York cop. So when he was arrested, they undoubtedly read him his rights as if he was an American citizen and he undoubtedly, unless he has judge confident to be able to wave his right to an attorney.

He's undoubtedly already been appointed an attorney, either from one of many groups who apologize for these guys in pro bono represent them or from a lawyer that's paid for by taxpayer, paid for about the very people he is trying to kill.

CASONE: I'll tell you what, former congressman and fox contributor Jason Chaffetz thinks that we need to go further with this guy. I want you to listen to what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX CONTRIBUTOR: Come to United States is a privilege. But, how do you do it and I see a mug shot. Now if you are come here to this country, and you've got an arrest record, you shouldn't get not get in, if you are here and you get arrested, and you just kick him out, that is a privilege to be here. We don't need people like that here and you should get rid of his family -- his entire family should be deported.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The family, James, what do you -- what do you make of that?

MITCHELL: Well, it depends on whether they are U.S. citizens or not and it depends on whether or not they were, you know, aiding and abetting his crime. I think it would be a useful tool to have if the family actually deserved to be treated that way.

But if they are innocent and they don't, I think it's a little bit draconian, but it would be nice to have that because here is the -- here is the problem, and this, I don't know his wife, I don't know who she is.

She may be neurosurgeon or a rocket scientist I don't know but odds are pretty good -- the odds are pretty good that she is not. And the odds are pretty good that she is going to be on our welfare system. So again, the very people he is trying to kill are going to end up supporting him.

CASONE: Well -- and there are children involved, too. So it's -- it's going to be...

(CROSSTALK)

MITCHELL: Absolutely, those children are already United States Citizens.

CASONE: Yes, James, thank you very much. We really appreciate having you here tonight on this.

MITCHELL: All right, thank you so much for having me.

CASONE: All right, James Mitchell. Well, we're going to take a quick break, when we come back, again, we're waiting to hear official the charges against the suspect in the New York City terror attacks. You are watching Risk and Reward, stay with us.

CASONE: Once again, I want to show you these live pictures. We're waiting right now on a press conference. It's about to begin, they are going to announce -- we are told, federal terrorism charges against Sayfullo Saipov related to yesterday's deadly attack in lower Manhattan, killing eight, injuring 12. I want to bring in right now as we await for this to get under way, former FBI counterterrorism task force member, Steve Rogers, a good friend to the program.

Steve, you know, this -- there was so much back and forth today politically about how he should be charged. President Trump said, sent him in Guantanamo Bay but this is going to be a -- he's going to be a federal criminal case basically, he is getting a lawyer. He may already be zipping his lip. What do you make on all of these?

STEVE ROGERS, FORMER MEMBER FBI COUNTERTERRORISM TASK FORCE: And that's the tragedy of what we're dealing with. You know, Cheryl, we're at war, and until the government and I am talking about whether we have Congress or whatever realized is that we're at war, we're going to continue to see this terrorist go down this road of being prosecuted as criminals and not enemy combatants.

So when you are at war, and you've got the enemy radicalizing their warriors here in this country, or if they are coming for overseas, they are enemy combatants. So he should be tried in a military court.

CASONE: But obviously that is not going to happen. I guess the point being though and -- tell you what, a few moments ago, we thought that press conference was going to start, Ryan Nash, the hero police officer from the NYPD came out to say thank you for outpouring of support.

I am so glad we had that moment, because he was the there and obviously saved lives. I mean, it was amazing what he shot him right away, and the suspect lived.

ROGERS: You know what a way to humanize our police officers, you know, we hear so many negative things but here is a young man who really, really served his country, let alone the city well, and God bless him and all of the law enforcement officers who have to protect and serve us.

CASONE: Yes, so he came on and he spoke but obviously now we move to next phase of this. This is going to be a very long drawn out process, the suspect is from Uzbekistan, not is not a citizen of the United State. He has family here. There is a lot that we don't know.

But we do know that he attend a mosque in New Jersey that had been on NYPD watch list for years. That is somewhat troubling. We do know -- we heard from the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee yesterday on Bret Baier show last night actually.

That they had a picture that came out in August as somebody taking a picture of that exact walkway in that exact spot among the bike path on West Side with an ISIS flag in the picture, this was planned, he planned this, we've been told this already, this information leaking out to Fox Newsahead of these charges.

ROGERS: Well you know, there are questions asked if he was on law enforcement radar, what happened? And I can tell you this, the FBI and law enforcement agencies, they are doing the best they could with what they have, and unfortunately, we don't have the human intelligence assets we use to have.

Those are boots on the ground, eyes on suspect, we are great at electronic intercepts, so I know the Trump administration is moving toward brining for example, community policing back in, so cops know, who, what, when, where and why in their neighborhoods, at the same time, more money will be put into counterterrorism, putting boots on ground to follow people.

That is how we brought the old mob down. We have organized crime then yet, cops in the cars, physically surveying people. You're going to see that come back. It is interesting from high-tech back to low tech.

CASONE: Yes, but at the same time, you have to think -- I mean this is New York City. This is the worst terror attack that we've seen in New York since 9/11. It is troubling that we are still vulnerable.

But to Mayor de Blasio's point, to Governor Cuomo's point, we can't be held hostage by terrorists, whether its ISIS inspired or lone wolf or whatever you want to call it, that's being debated. We can't be held hostage as New Yorkers, and those are Americans. They hate our way of life. They want us to suffer, and this is maybe just our new reality.

ROGERS: Well you know what, we're not being held hostage because we're still moving on. The World Series is on, the football game is on, everything that we live by is moving on, but what we can do, situational awareness is something that we need to talk about down the road, you talked about guy with the flag, somebody took a picture. If you see something, say something and so many times people say, I don't want to bother the police, bother the police.

CASONE: There are plenty of them around especially in this city. Steve, I want you to stay with me, we continue to monitor of course those live picture, we're waiting the official federal charges to be announced against the suspect in the terror attack here in New York City. We're taking a quick commercial break, stay with us, we'll be right back with that.

CASONE: Once again, I want to let you know, press conference about to begin to announce federal terrorism changes against Sayfullo Saipov, related to yesterday's deadly attack here in lower Manhattan. We're going to -- we expecting to see Joon Kim, the acting United States Attorney for southern district as well as William Sweeney. He is from the FBI, and James O'Neill, the New York Police commissioner.

You may have seen him yesterday, when he was there standing, of course they are giving us those first early details in that press confront held with Mayor Bill de Blasio and also with New York Governor Andrew Cuomo. They are testing the microphone, we're told this is going to start at any moment, I've got Steve Rogers with me as we wait.

And in break, Steve, we were talking about the fact that being here in city yesterday as we were, you almost wonder if we're desensitized to things like this, and if that is a dangerous thing. I have my friends worried about where am I going to take my kids trick or treating, not are we safe in this city.

ROGERS: It's very dangerous and we are so inundated with violence, T.V., radio, news script or you hear about it, even these new movies come out, all violence, and that's all we're being fed, and now a real, true, real life violent act happens, are we desensitized. We have to be very careful to not fall asleep and to know what's going on around us.

CASONE: You know, obviously, the general manner are there. They are kind of starting to assemble and we will take this, until they start talking but certainly again, the big -- actually here we go, this is Joon Kim, he is the acting U.S. attorney for southern district of New York. Let's listen in.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOON KIM, ACTING U.S. ATTORNEY, SOUTHERN DISTRICT, NEW YORK: Good evening. My name is Joon Kim. I am the acting United States Attorney for southern district of New York. Yesterday afternoon, a man consumed by hate and a twisted ideology attacked our country and our city.

Using a rented home depot truck as his weapon of terror the man sped down West Side Highway, and then intentionally plowed his truck into a pedestrian walkway and bicycle path, hitting and running over people who were simply trying to enjoy a sunny afternoon in New York City.

He killed eight innocent human beings and injured at least a dozen other people. That man has alleged in a complaint filed today was Sayfullo Saipov. Today, thanks to the incredible work of the FBI, the NYPD, Joint Terrorism Tasks Force, and law enforce in the city and around the country, just about 24 hours after Sayfullo Saipov attack, we have him charged with federal crimes of terrorism.

The complaint filed today, charges Saipov with two counts, first, material support of a terrorist organization, that being ISIS and second, a federal charge of violence and destruction of a motor vehicle with willful disregard for the safety of human life that resulted in multiple deaths.

At the complaint alleges, after speeding through the walkway and bicycle paths, run over and killing people, Saipov crashed his truck into a school bus, carrying children. The he got out, yelled, Allah Akbar, meaning, God is great, brandishing two weapons, which turned out to be a paintball gun and a pellet gun. He was ultimately stopped by a brave police officer, Ryan Nash, who confronted him and shot him in the abdomen.

In the short time since this attack as alleged in the complain, we have developed evidence establishing that Saipov committed this attack in support of ISIS. That evidence is laid out in the complaint, but it includes the following. A note that was recovered just outside the truck, that read in part, no God, but God, and Mohammed is his prophet, and Islamic supplication, it will endure.

A phrase commonly used to refer to ISIS. Also, a search of cell phones found in a bag that he was carrying, a search conducted pursue to court authorize wiretaps, revealed thousands of ISIS related images, and 90 videos -- about 90 videos, depicting among other things, ISIS fighters, killing prisoners by running over them with a tank, beheading them, and shooting them in the face.

In Mirandized interview statements with law enforcement last night and today, Saipov allegedly admitted that he was inspired to commit the attack by the ISIS videos he watched and had been planning this attack for two months. He also admitted that he had rented a truck on October 22nd, in practice -- to practice the turns he would make on his Halloween day attack.

As I mentioned, it is incredible investigative work that had allowed us to bring the changes so soon after the attacks. I want to thank all law enforcement and citizens who responded to this attack in the way New Yorkers do. In particular, I want to thank Officer Ryan Nash, for his selfless bravery.

I want to thank the FBI represented here today by Bill Sweeney, assistant director in-charge of the New York field office. Their work in this case, as in all terrorism matters that we've worked with them on has been extraordinary. I also want to thank the NYPD, represented here today by first deputy commissioner Benjamin Tucker, and deputy Commissioner John Miller.

Their leadership and that of Commissioner O'Neill, over the greatest police force in the world has helped keep our city safe, and in the wake of yesterday's attacks, the NYPD has kept our citizens reassured and continuing to live our lives. Finally, I want to thank the terrorism prosecutors and investigators in my office who jumped on this immediately and haven't gotten any sleep since.

(Inaudible) who are all -- were not here because they are in court at the presentment. And investigators Kevin Song (ph) and George Corey (ph), as well as the supervisors of our Terrorism International Unit who are here with me, John Buckley and (Inaudible).

To folks in that unit working with the FBI, the NYPD, the JTTF, having a long and unblemished track record of successfully investigating and prosecuting domestic and international terrorists, whether it's the Chelsea bomber, just convicted a few weeks ago on all counts and who will be serving life -- mandatory life in prison.

Or the other terrorists convicted in our courthouse, just down the street in the last few years alone. That list includes the recent convictions by this office at the trial of Suleiman Abu Ghaith, Osama bin Laden's son-in- law.

Abu Hamza, the United Kingdom-based radical cleric. (Inaudible), the homegrown ISIS supporter and khalid al-Fawwaz, one of al-Qaeda's embassy bombing defendants. It's an amazing record of success. Of the eight innocent people, Saipov allegedly killed yesterday, two were Americans. And the rest were foreigners visiting New York City. It has been reported that five of eight victims were childhood friends from Argentina celebrating a high school reunion --
