Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60S1-DNC1-DXP9-90W6-00000-00Tesla and the audacity of hype2020-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisTesla and the audacity of hypeJohn Thornhill

Nikola Tesla was one of the world’s most brilliant, if eccentric, inventors. While not out feeding pigeons on night-time strolls, the Serbia... Nikola Tesla was one of the world’s most brilliant, if eccentric, inventors. While not out feeding pigeons on night-time strolls, the Serbian-American engineer reimagined the uses of electricity, radio and robotics and patented 278 inventions....

Nikola Tesla was one of the world’s most brilliant, if eccentric, inventors. While not out feeding pigeons on night-time strolls, the Serbia...

Nikola Tesla was one of the world’s most brilliant, if eccentric, inventors. While not out feeding pigeons on night-time strolls, the Serbian-American engineer reimagined the uses of electricity, radio and robotics and patented 278 inventions. But he died in poverty in 1943. 

By a cruel twist of fate, the electric car company named in Tesla’s honour has become one of the most extraordinary, wealth-creating stock market machines in history. In spite of the sharp sell-off in tech stocks this week, Tesla’s share price has more than quadrupled this year. Run by Elon Musk, Tesla is currently valued at about $379bn, one and a quarter times more than Toyota and Volkswagen combined.

If Barack Obama won the US presidency in 2008 on the audacity of hope, then the maverick Mr Musk has built his career on the audacity of hype. The fast-tweeting, pot-smoking, rocket-launching Mr Musk is not just selling cars but a ticket to the future, supporters claim. He promises yet another “mind-blowing” announcement about Tesla’s battery technology later this month.

The market euphoria surrounding Tesla has rubbed off on other electric vehicle companies as investors have scrambled to find the next wonder stock. Last week, Xpeng Motors, a Chinese EV manufacturer, jumped 40 per cent on its stock market debut in New York, benefiting from a “Tesla halo”. Its heavily oversubscribed listing valued the start-up at $10bn. 

Such nosebleed valuations surely scream: “BUBBLE!” And the market certainly paused for thought this week. No traditional investment metrics, such as price earnings ratios or dividend yields, can possibly justify Tesla’s stratospheric share price. Tesla makes minimal earnings and pays no dividend. 

For comparison, Toyota and Volkswagen jointly produced 21.8m cars and generated $15.6bn of free cash flow in 2019, according to JPMorgan. That same year, Tesla made 366,000 cars and $1.1bn of cash. Looked at another way, the stock market “values” every car Tesla sold last year at over $1m apiece. You can buy a Tesla Model 3 for $35,000.

A punchy bear case has been made by Jamie Powell on FT Alphaville who argues Tesla’s share price is unhinged from economic reality. We have returned to the world of “dot.comedy” of 2000 just before markets crashed. 

Such scepticism does not worry Mr Musk’s fans, who cheer his every move and aggressively troll his doubters. Nor does it seem to concern some mainstream investors, who argue Tesla is a bet on three big technological trends: electric cars, battery technology and autonomous driving. Morgan Stanley forecasts that Tesla will sell 6m cars by 2030 and can generate rapidly increasing high-margin revenue from services and batteries. The company is as much about software as it is about hardware, a bet that an iPhone on wheels is a lot more valuable than a tin can. 

This week, Baillie Gifford, one of Tesla’s biggest shareholders, cut its investment for portfolio weighting reasons, booking profits of $17bn in eight months. But the Edinburgh-based fund management group said it remained optimistic about Tesla’s future and retained a 4.25 per cent stake.

James Anderson, co-manager of Baillie Gifford’s flagship fund, says it is sometimes worth paying “unreasonable prices” for high-growth tech stocks. The bears have been blinded by misguided concepts of value investing and index tracking. To understand the new economy, Mr Anderson suggests, it is far more instructive to read the annual shareholder letters of Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, than those of Warren Buffett, the high priest of the value investment movement.

Two contentions underpin Baillie Gifford’s investment approach. First, returns in stock markets are infinitely more extreme and concentrated than most people assume. Citing the research of Hendrik Bessembinder, a professor at Arizona State University, Mr Anderson says: “All the excess returns in world markets since 1990 have come from just 1.3 per cent of companies.”

Second, some of these intellectual property-rich companies, such as Google and Alibaba, generate increasing, rather than diminishing, returns because of scale effects in a networked world, as described by Brian Arthur, professor at the Santa Fe Institute.

To be sure, Tesla’s current valuation looks irrational. But rationality has been stretched thin in all kinds of ways in 2020. In a world awash with central bank cash, many other market valuations look just as screwy. There are now about $14tn of global bonds trading on negative yields.

The other big difference with 2000 is that many highly valued tech companies, if not Tesla, are massively profitable. From that perspective, Big Tech’s valuations may reflect an excessive concentration of corporate power. That should be of more immediate interest to antitrust regulators than short sellers.

At Baillie Gifford, Mr Anderson concedes it is pointless to try to time the market’s next move. But he remains convinced of the worth of active fund management and the long-term transformations wrought by technology. “Over the past 15 years we have made an awful lot of mistakes,” he says. “But our biggest mistake may be that we have not been optimistic enough.”

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:609B-6S21-F03R-N30T-00000-00Tesla Brings S3XY Back; Spot the Triple-Digit Winner2020-07-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:07ZLexisNexisTesla Brings S3XY Back; Spot the Triple-Digit WinnerJoseph Hargett

Jul 06, 2020( Banyan Hill: http://banyanhill.com Delivered by Newstex) ;; Tesla Wears on Short ShortsGood Monday, dear reader! Did you have a great Fourth of July celebration? (Otherwise known as national 'scare the crap out of your dog' day.) If the fireworks finally died down in your neighborhood (lucky!)

and you're jonesing for more, Wall Street has you covered. More specifically, Tesla Inc. (Nasdaq: TSLA[1]) has you covered in short red shorts. Over the weekend, the ever-effervescent CEO Elon Musk took aim at TSLA short sellers once again. Musk tweeted out 'Who wears short shorts?' followed by a link to buy limited edition Tesla short shorts[2]. The shorts have Tesla's logo on the front and 'S3XY' on the back, a reference to Tesla vehicle models. The shorts were clearly aimed at Tesla bears, one of which — Stanphyl Capital[3] — laid out extensive reasoning last week why you should sell TSLA right now. But Musk once again had the last laugh. TSLA shares are up more than 200% this year, riding solid vehicle deliveries and a streak of three consecutive profitable quarters. Profitability has long been Tesla's biggest drag, especially among short sellers. But, if second-quarter deliveries — which came in at 90,000 vehicles, above Wall Street's most bullish estimates — are any indication, Tesla is set to extend that winning streak to four quarters, something the company has never done before. Will that silence TSLA short sellers? Probably not. Short sellers gotta short, and bears will jump through any number of hoops to do so. For instance, J.P. Morgan Analyst Ryan Brinkman grudgingly lifted his price target on TSLA from $275 to $295[4] this morning, citing Tesla's deliveries report. Yes, you read that right: a price target of $295 on a $1,313-plus stock. Now, Brinkman and Stanphyl Capital might be right. I'm not saying they are, but it's possible. However, you can be right and still lose a lot of money. Betting against Telsa right now is a surefire way to do just that. Luckily for TSLA short sellers, they can now 'run like the wind or entertain like Liberace[5]' in their new Tesla short shorts for just $69.420. Maybe a little exercise in Tesla shorts will help relieve the chafing from their TSLA shorts. Editor's Note: Chafing. Are you tired of chafing? I'm tired of chafing. With TSLA constantly hitting all-time highs, it's tough to nail down an entry point. That really smarts, and a pair of little red Tesla shorts won't change that. I say it's time to put an end to chafing over TSLA shares — and find a better way to play the electric vehicle (EV) market! The real potential for your investment dollar lies in energy technology — specifically, a crucial piece of tech developed by one tiny, pioneering American company. It's an energy revolution that could create more millionaires than pot stocks, cryptos and Big Tech combined! So quit chafing over Tesla. Click here to learn more![6] Good: Me and My Shadow Tesla's Chinese shadow, Nio Inc. (NYSE: NIO[7]) also stole headlines today. DigiTimes reported that Nio sold 3,740 EVs[8] in June, spiking 179% year over year. What's more, Nio sold 10,331 EVs in the first half of 2020. That's up 191% from last year and above the company's original estimate for sales of 9,500 to 10,000. The company also announced plans to ramp up production from 4,000 units per month to 4,500 to 5,000 per month. So far, Tesla's success in China has proven to be Nio's success as well. The smaller Chinese rival continues to ride Tesla's coattails, albeit with a healthy dose of government support. That said, this serious home-field advantage may be what ultimately gives Nio an edge in China. Because of this home-field advantage, I'm putting Nio on the Great Stuff watch list. In other words, we'll look for a reasonable entry price once the current rally hype dies down. Stay tuned for more!Better: Uber Eats Postmates It's no secret that Uber Technologies Inc. (NYSE: UBER[9]) was hungry. Last month, it tried to fill its belly with Grubhub. Alas, European food delivery company Takeaway.com drank Uber's milkshake[10]. But, let's be honest, the Uber-Grubhub deal never would've passed regulators' noses to begin with — 48% control of the U.S. food delivery market? Nope. Not happening. But today, Uber finally found a tasty treat in Postmates[11]. The privately held food delivery company was shaping up to be one of the hottest initial public offerings (IPO) of the year[12]. But those IPO dreams came to a halt today after Uber's board approved a $2.65 billion, all-stock offer for Postmates. Uber stock rose roughly 7% on the news. Investors clearly cheer Uber's support of its rising food delivery service — especially with the pandemic crippling the ride-sharing front. Last quarter, Uber lost $3 billion despite Uber Eats growing revenue at a 52% clip. More on earnings Armageddon in a second, because firstBest: Spot the Triple-Digit Winner Congratulations are in order, dear reader! Today, Great Stuff Picks is closing out our fourth triple-digit winner of the year! We recommended music streaming giant Spotify Technology S.A. (NYSE: SPOT[13]) back in June 2019, when the stock traded around $127. Today, SPOT hovers around $265. That's a 108% gain in about a year's time! Spotify has come on big in 2020, fueled by podcast deals like those with popular podcasters Bill Simmons and Joe Rogan. Analysts at RiskHedge[14] believe that the company is 'rapidly becoming something of a monopoly in the audio industry,' while others believe that Spotify's 'blue-sky growth' is over. There are still bullish parameters in play for Spotify. There really isn't a competitor that stands up to Spotify in terms of price, content and user base growth. It's quickly becoming a household name for streaming music. However, I believe that the hype behind Spotify will settle down over the next month or so as investors take profits. Keeping with our mantra of 'don't be greedy,' Great Stuff is taking our 100% gain and going home. If SPOT revisits the $200 area in a pullback, we'll reevaluate buying back in. But for now: Sell SPOT.Would you look at the time! It's almost earnings season again. This time around, analysts and masochists alike expect a rude awakening, like firecrackers in your cornflakes. Today's Chart of the Week comes from a Yahoo Finance article that wasn't quite the Monday morning pep talk I was looking for: 'Get Ready for the Ugliest Earnings Season Since the Financial Crisis[15].' Aren't you ready?! I'm chomping at the bit, myself. Here's what analysts predict about the nigh-approaching earnings season:Here we can see bottom-up earnings projected to run off a cliff like Wile E. Coyote, followed by a prim-and-proper rebound to whisk away the unpleasantries. But Mr. Great Stuff, you've seen the numbers, what earnings didn't go bottom-up this season? You jest but here's a little market lingo to stick in your quiver. Bottom-up simply refers to earnings. A lot of different factors affect earnings, including the coronavirus prep and cleaning costs. Earnings results more directly affect shareholders, or at least they're supposed to — I'm looking at you, 2020. Top-down, meanwhile, refers to a company's revenue, which typically excludes pesky things like taxes and costs that aren't from straight-up sales. Top-down investing looks at these figures as a better reflection of actual economic activity — a company's big-picture growth, if you will. Now our Chart of the Week has some context or does it? You see, it's not the highlighted second-quarter dip that worries me — that's already priced into the market. No, it's the rosy rebound in the third and fourth quarters that doesn't jive with rising COVID-19 cases. Those projections were laid out while expecting the Great Reopening to go off without a hitch. That the U.S. economy would come roaring back once nationwide lockdowns were lifted. They were made without the prospect of a second wave of COVID-19 infections or economic blackouts rolling across the country as counties and states reclose their economies to deal with the pandemic (again). Just like we said months ago nobody's timing this. I'd love for earnings to roar back to life like a round trip to the Pet Sematary, but the only timeline that matters here is the virus's timeline. On that note, from Bank of America's Savita Subramanian: 'At this point, exactly 400 companies within the S&P 500 have failed to guide over the last three months suggesting that corporate sentiment is neither positive nor negative, but simply a big question mark.' Here's my point: We can basically throw out those early earnings and economic projections. What does that leave us with? A big ol' question mark. And we all know how Wall Street loves uncertainty. One thing's for certain: We're headed for an explosive tell-all earnings season. As always, Great Stuff will keep you in the loop!Great Stuff: Keep It LoopyWhat a Monday! Did you have a fun and festive weekend? Are you ready for another round of earnings season showdowns? Do you need an outlet for your stock ideas and rambling rants? GreatStuffToday@BanyanHill.com [16] is the most happening inbox around. Why not send us a quick memo?; Remember, if you got into our Spotify trade, we'd love to hear from you too! And if you're still scratching around for a Great Stuff Pick, keep your eye out. We're always on the prowl for new Picks and what's shaking on Shakedown Street. You can also use our social media to stay on top of the Great Stuff action: Facebook[17], Instagram[18] and Twitter[19]. Until next time, stay Great! urn:contentItem:5M4F-92X1-JCMN-Y0GC-00000-00Tesla buys German manufacturing plant to speed up production2016-11-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisTesla buys German manufacturing plant to speed up productionSteven Loeb

Nov 08, 2016( Vator News: http://vator.tv/news Delivered by Newstex) This is only Tesla's third acquisition ever, and its second this year, after SolarCityTesla is a bit of a rarity for a company of its size. While other big tech companies like Yahoo and Google have, at times, made upwards of 20 purchases a year, Tesla really doesn't make many acquisitions at all. Prior to this year, in fact, it had only made one acquisition.

This year is a total outlier, it has now made two in just the last three months. The company announced on Tuesday that it has acquired[1] Grohmann Engineering, a German engineering firm that specializes in automated manufacturing processes. No financial terms of the deal were disclosed. The purchase will give Elon Musk's company a new factory that will allow Tesla to increase its productivity, aiding its goal of bringing number of cars manufactured to half a million a year by 2018. "Accelerating a sustainable energy future is only possible with high-volume factories. They allow us to manufacture high-quality products with economies of scale, making them more affordable and accessible to the world," the company wrote. "As the machine that builds the machine, our factories are so important that we believe they will ultimately deserve an order of magnitude more attention in engineering than what they produce. At very high production volumes, the factory becomes more of a product than the product itself." Going forward, Grohmann Engineering will be renamed as TeslaGrohmann Automation, and it will serve as the initial base for Tesla Advanced Automation Germany headquarters, with other locations to follow. The company will continue to be led by founder and CEO Klaus Grohmann.  Tesla said that it expects to add over 1,000 advanced engineering and skilled technician jobs in Germany over the next two years. The deal isn't quite done yet, as it still needs to be cleared by regulators, including in Germany, but the company is seeking to have the acquisition completed in only a few months, by early 2017. Tesla is riding high right now. In its most recent earnings, the company posted its second profitable quarter ever, earning $2.3 billion, beating expectations of $1.98 billion. The company also revealed[2] that it delivered approximately 24,500 vehicles in the quarter, up 70 percent quarter-to-quarter, while production rose 37 percent to 25,185 vehicles, both record numbers. Over a quarter, 25.1 percent of the company, was acquired from private equity firm Deutsche Beteiligungs AG.  'With its technology leadership, Grohmann exemplifies the hidden champions in Germany's Mittelstand, without which key innovations would not occur,' Torsten Grede, Spokesman of the Board of Management of Deutsche Beteiligungs AG, said in a statement[3]. 'Grohmann is an outstanding example of the excellent progress technology-geared Mittelstand companies can make backed by growth capital and the support of professional investors.' According to Deutsche Beteiligungs, Grohmann revenues have been growing by an average of more than six percent annually over the last 20 years, reaching 123 million euros in 2015. The number of employees tripled over the same period to approximately 700.  This is Tesla's second proposed acquisition of the year, announcing[4] this summer that it would combine with SolarCity, a solar energy company, which Musk also helped start, and which he serves as chairman. Prior to this year, Tesla had made one other purchase, buying Riviera Tool[5], a producer of tools and dies that stamp out metal parts, in early 2015. That allowed the company to expand operations to Michigan, the location of one of its three egineering facilities; the others are in Fremont, California, and now Germany.  Shares of Tesla stock are up 1.87 percent, trading at $196.83 a share. (Image source: abcnews.go.com[6])Read this article on Vator.tv at http://vator.tv/n/481b[7] [ 1]:   https://www.tesla.com/blog/formation-of-tesla-advanced-automation-germany [ 2]:   http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=991720 [ 3]:   https://www.dbag.de/press-releases-details/?cms_press_id=2004 [ 4]:   https://www.tesla.com/blog/tesla-and-solarcity-combine [ 5]:   http://finance.yahoo.com/news/tesla-tsla-acquires-michigan-based-210009392.html [ 6]:   http://abcnews.go.com/topics/business/automotive/tesla-motors.htm [ 7]:   http://vator.tv/news/2016-11-08-tesla-buys-german-manufacturing-plant-to-speed-up-production

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60K3-YWS1-JB20-G2B4-00000-00Tesla gets a jolt on 5-1 stock split; TikTok tracked user data; College football takes a timeout; Joe Biden taps Kamala Harris as running mate; McConnell blasts Democrats for stalling virus relief talks; Health officials skeptical of Russia's COVID-19 vaccine; Facebook curbing news pages with political ties; Airbnb plans to file for IPO this month; Whole Foods launches free cooking classes2020-08-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTRonna McDaniel, Jonathan Madison, Jonathan Ward, Mark Penn, Jonathan Madison, Ryan Payne, Daniel CulverNEWSFinancial081201cb.231Tesla gets a jolt on 5-1 stock split; TikTok tracked user data; College football takes a timeout; Joe Biden taps Kamala Harris as running mate; McConnell blasts Democrats for stalling virus relief talks; Health officials skeptical of Russia's COVID-19 vaccine; Facebook curbing news pages with political ties; Airbnb plans to file for IPO this month; Whole Foods launches free cooking classesMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Dagen McDowell, Lou Dobbs

LOU DOBBS, HOST, FBN HOST: A reminder to follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight. Thank you for being with us. Good night from Sussex.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Happy Wednesday everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Good morning to you. It is Wednesday, August 12th, your top stories right now at 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The Democratic ticket is set, Joe Biden tapping Senator Kamala Harris as his running mate; President Trump's reaction straight ahead. Stimulus stalemate, still no deal with Congress as the White House pushes forward on executive orders to help Americans.

Coming up at 8:30 a.m. Eastern this morning, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is here, live on where the talks stand and how soon Americans could see extra unemployment benefits.

Tesla trying to electrify investors, announcing a 5-1 stock split. The stock is shifting into high gear on the news; we are looking at a 5% rally right now.

Broad markets also higher, take a look at Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading. The Dow Futures currently up 250 points, that's about 1%. The NASDAQ Futures up 92 and the S&P Futures up 25.

The stimulus standoff leading to a late day sell-off yesterday, meanwhile the S&P 500 snapped a seven day winning streak at 4 o'clock on Wall Street but the S&P down 26, the Dow down 105 and the NASDAQ lower by 185. Gold also losing some of its shine, gold prices back below $2,000 announced now after tumbling 4.5% yesterday.

More TikTok security concerns this morning. The popular Chinese app reportedly tracking user data from millions of people, in violation of Google policies. Plus college football taking a time out, the Big Ten and Pac-12 postponing the fall season due to the coronavirus.

Mornings with Maria is live right now

And global markets this morning are mixed. The FTSE 100 in London is up 48 points, the UK economy falling into a recession after shrinking by more than 20% in the second quarter, the largest contraction reported by any major economy so far. The CAC quarante in Paris was up 12 and the DAX Index in Germany lower by 18 points this morning.

Check Asian markets overnight mostly higher on the session, take a look. KOSPI Index was higher as was the Hang Seng. Hong Kong up 1.5% overnight. Shanghai Composite in China, lower.

Now, some of the top stores that we are watching this morning. Historic decision, Joe Biden tapping Kamala Harris as his pick for Vice President. The California Senator is the daughter of Indian and Jamaican parents. She makes history as the first woman of color on a major Presidential ticket. President Trump already slamming the decision, calling Harris one of the most liberal members of the Senate.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: As far as Kamala is concerned, she's a big tax raiser, slasher of funds for our military, and she's got a lot of difficult things that she's going to have to explain.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Harris and Biden will make their first appearance as running mates later today in Delaware. No more games, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell demanding Democrats to restart coronavirus relief negotiations. McConnell says if Democrats are playing hardball, they are only harming vulnerable Americans, not Republicans. President Trump signed executive orders last weekend extending certain relief benefits to keep the stimulus on the move.

Tesla is on the move this morning. Shares are up in the free market. The electric vehicle maker announced last night a 5-1 stock split. Tesla shares gaining 229% this year, hitting a string of closing records. As you see, the stock is up 5.5% right now. This split goes into effect after the close of trading August 31; couple of weeks now.

College football on the bench. The Big Ten and Pac-12 taking a time out, sidelining players to the upcoming fall season due to the coronavirus concerns. Officials say the health of student athletes is most important. The conferences are now on pushing the season to the spring.

And the 2020 presidential race officially on the Democratic ticket set, Joe Biden taps Senator Kamala Harris as his nitpick for Vice President. Biden tweeted this out, "I have the great honor to announce that I have picked Kamala Harris, a fearless fighter for the little guy and one of the country's finest public servants as my running mate."

Harris tweeted this in response, "Joe Biden can unify the American people because he spent his life fighting for us, and as President, he will build an America that lives up to our ideals. I'm honored to join him as our Party's nominee for Vice President and do what it takes to make him our Commander-in-Chief," writes Kamala Harris.

President Trump weighed in as well. He spoke with Sean Hannity in a Fox News exclusive last night

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: She wants to raise taxes. She wants to get rid of your Second Amendment. No guns for protection, no nothing. She's very strong in the Second Amendment, getting rid of it and very bad to the military.

She wants to cut the military, she wants to cut spending for the military, and the vets. And I don't quite get the choice, but we'll have it out. We have a great Vice President named Mike Pence and he will take care of business just like he did the last time against a different candidate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Biden and Harris will make their first campaign event together today in Delaware. Joining me right now is Former Senior Advisor to the Clintons. He is the CEO of MDC Partners and Stagwell Group President and Managing Partner Mark Penn. Also joining the conversation this morning is Fox Business' Dagen McDowell, Republican Strategist and Fried & Williams Attorney Jonathan Madison, along with Payne Capital Management President Ryan Payne.

Great to see everybody this morning, thanks so much for being here. Mark Penn, kick it off with you. Your reaction to Biden's pick, Kamala gets the job.

MARK PENN, PRESIDENT AND MANAGING DIRECTOR, STAGWELL GROUP: Well, I think as I said last time, I thought it was the obvious pick, probably the smartest pick of the choices that he had assembled. It certainly unifies the Democratic Party. There's not going to be a split or a fight.

It gives a momentum; frankly I don't know why didn't they do this weeks earlier. Obviously, Biden had some reservations, he cleared up those reservations, and then went forward with a safer choice I think than any of the others before them.

BARTIROMO: Would you call Kamala Harris moderate?

PENN: Moderate in the Democratic Party as it is today, but yes, sure. I think she is going to be backing higher taxes, regulations on guns. She backed up the New Green Deal. But in terms of the Democratic Party itself and her true history, over a longer term, she was more moderate before she got into the Democratic primary and I don't know what she's going to be on the stump, but she has a real record as someone who served the public well and I think she will wear well as a Vice Presidential pick.

BARTIROMO: Well, Dagen McDowell, jump in here because the reason that I ask is just for that reason, she's backing the Green Deal, she's backing these higher taxes. I'm wondering if she has been pulled all the way to the Left by those hijacking this party, Dagen, that's why I asked the question.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, Joe Biden has been, and Mark talked about this the last time he was on the show that Joe Biden has been pulled to the left.

Normally, you move to the center after the primary season, not so much with Joe Biden that he's being pulled further and further left. So she kind of fits in with that in a way. But Mark, what does Kamala Harris bring, the Senator, to swing States and suburban swing state voters? Does she have any impact there because that's where the rubber meets the road in the Presidential Election?

PENN: Well, I think she brings three things. One, she brings unity within the Democratic Party. I don't think that there'll be a significant challenge to her. I think she does bring record as a prosecutor. The time she was criticized for being too tough, I think you'll see her swing into that mode, right, and she is a historic nomination.

So I think those three things, and she's not going to be at variance with Joe Biden. I think whatever positions he takes, I think she's going to be a supporter and I think she'll be a reasonably effective debater. I think I'll want to see the Pence-Kamala Harris debate. I think it could be a really strong debate on the issues before the country.

BARTIROMO: So what about the issue of crime and this vandalism taking place and this crime numbers rising throughout so many of our big cities, Mark? How do you see her dealing with that as a former prosecutor?

PENN: Well, I think that's a big question. I think Biden has come out against the violence, but really hasn't made it a theme of the campaign. And so I think that President Trump has actually put a pretty strong contrast against Biden and the Democrats on this issue.

And particularly as violence continued, I think it's more of a weakness than strength. So I'd like to see the Democrats come out much more strongly condemning violence and clearly so, while at the same time, condemning racial inequality. I think it's a false choice that's been set up here.

BARTIROMO: Yes, so what else does she bring in terms of being the former AG in California? How does she use that resume to actually bring value and make a difference as Vice President?

PENN: Well, I think as Vice President, she'll say, look, I went after criminals, I was a cop (ph), I pulled no punches, I'm ready to go toe-to- toe with Mike Pence and I'm ready to take the Democratic platform and with Joe Biden once he is President, articulated, get out there.

She's certainly shown that she's willing to be a tough campaigner. She obviously attacked Joe Biden. It didn't work as effectively as she was hoping, but I think she will get out there and be what a Vice Presidential pick is generally thought of these days, as someone who's able to carry on the fight. And I think she's an articulate and skilled debater.

So again, the number of choices, she is historic choice, she moves this ticket forward, probably should have done it two weeks earlier, but I think it'll get some momentum going into the campaign, into the convention.

BARTIROMO: Jonathan Madison, jump in.

JONATHAN MADISON, ATTORNEY, FRIED & WILLIAMS: I think it's awesome that she and I share the same alma mater, Howard University. Her resume obviously speaks for itself. That being said, I think she has two really big challenges.

The first of which is, it's ironic that she's the only candidate Joe Biden could have picked that went to a Howard University in HBCU, a historically black college. However, she had a tremendously tough time connecting with the black vote in, garnering the black vote in the Democratic primaries if you recall.

She didn't even make it past 2019 in the Democratic primaries in large part because she could not garner black votes. So if Joe Biden is attempting to use her to garner some black support and the black vote, particularly after he's made disparaging comments about the African American race over the past couple of months, he's got some tough times ahead.

The second issue is, she's going to have to connect with voters on the Rust Belt and that's not going to be a very easy thing for her to do, having been a District Attorney in a place like San Francisco for seven years. Whether you're connecting with Democrats in the Rust Belt, whether you're connecting with Republicans, everyone in between, she's got some tough day there.

BARTIROMO: Yes, these are great points. Mark, what do you say?

PENN: Well, I don't think it's going to be her job to connect with the Rust Belt.

BARTIROMO: Would there connecting with the African-American - yes.

PENN: Well, A, I don't think it's going to her job to connect with the Rust Belt. I think that's going to be Joe Biden's job. And he's right, she didn't pull the African American vote as strongly as she expected and everyone expected during the primaries. I don't think anybody ever really explained why that happened and Biden held on to his share of the vote.

Look, together as a ticket, I think they're going to do very, very well with the African American vote. A lot of people will see her as a potential second African-American President now that she has this nomination. I wouldn't worry about her not performing well out there on the stump with these poor Democratic constituencies. I think that she is a safe pick, a good pick, and this race is not going to be about the Vice Presidential choice. It's going to be about other issues.

BARTIROMO: Yes, alright Mark. Great to see you this morning, thanks so much.

PENN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Mark Penn joining us. Now in the morning mover, Moderna. Take a look at the stock surging this morning after the White House announced a deal for the biotech company's coronavirus vaccine.

We are just getting started this morning. Coming up, quick break and then the RNC Chair Ronna McDaniel is here to talk about Kamala Harris as Joe Biden's Vice Presidential pick. Then Atlas Organization's Founder Jonathan Ward is here talking about Jimmy Lai's latest arrest in Hong Kong.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A big claim from Moscow. Russia approving what it is calling the world's first coronavirus vaccine, though many have their doubts. Global health officials saying that the vaccine has yet to go through critical late-stage trials. But Russian President Vladimir Putin says his own daughter has taken it.

Joining us right now is Pulmonary and Critical Care Physician at the Cleveland Clinic, Dr. Daniel Culver. And Dr. Culver, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks very much for joining us. What do we know about this vaccine? Is it safe? Compare what's happening in Russia to what the United States is doing in terms of efforts around a coronavirus vaccine?

DANIEL CULVER, PULMONOLOGIST, CLEVELAND CLINIC: Good morning. Thank you for having me. We really know very little about the vaccine. Broadly, we know that it's similar to a strategy used by the Oxford University, AstraZeneca Group and CanSino and Johnson & Johnson, but we don't know any of the data about how effective it was in early stage trials. We know very little about the plans for larger trials. And so, all we really know is a strategy right now. I think we'd like more information before we make judgments on it.

BARTIROMO: So a little propaganda in there. Let's turn to the United States and what Moderna is doing. The stock is up this morning. What vaccines can you talk about that are in development, that are actually showing promise? And I know Moderna is among them.

CULVER: Right, Moderna is among them. Several vaccine manufacturers have published results on early stage trials showing immune responses, both formation of antibodies and responses from the cell part of the immune system, and all four of those that have published the results so far, which includes Moderna, have shown that there may be potential benefits. But of course, those are in healthy patients, younger patients and we need to see how the vaccines act in larger populations, the people who are really at risk for this disease, and to look for rare side effects that can happen where you really need large populations to see those.

BARTIROMO: So, the President yesterday talked about the government's deal to purchase 100 million doses of Moderna's experimental coronavirus vaccine. When do you expect that? They're talking about later this year, perhaps October, November. It's pretty extraordinary that we're at this point in such a short period of time, right, for this agreement is for 100 million doses.

CULVER: Yes. I think that this is really a wonderful example of collaboration across academia, pharma and government. De-risking the process by allowing manufacturing of the vaccines now, I think really speeds things up. The question of when this will happen depends on the speed of enrolment of the trials. These are roughly looking at around 30,000 patients for the trials, the Pfizer drug, the Moderna vaccine. And so, we need to see how fast those trials enrol.

And then, it depends on how many people in the trials actually get exposed to the virus, because until there are enough events, it's very hard to judge whether or not the vaccine is effective. I think that October is perhaps ambitious. We'll have to see how it goes.

BARTIROMO: So, assess where we are here today, as far as this vaccine, do you feel that we're going to see another spike in the fall?

CULVER: Well, I think whether or not we see a spike really depends on behaviour, how closely people follow social distancing. What happens is people go back to schools, whether there's fatigue about things like mask wearing, and so it's really up to the American public about how big this virus gets in the fall. I do think that eventually there's likely to be a vaccine, but first we have to do those important blocking and tackling measures.

BARTIROMO: Dr. Daniel Culver, great to see you this morning, thanks very much for your insights. We'll keep watching and talk with you soon. Thank you, sir.

CULVER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, historic choice, Joe Biden taps Senator Kamala Harris as his Vice-Presidential pick. We are on it all morning this morning, taking a look at the impact on your life. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Senator Kamala Harris in the spotlight. MCDOWELL: I think her biggest impact will be, number one, she could go out of the House with ease, which clearly has been an issue for former Vice President Joe Biden. My friend Jenny Johnson tweeted this 'Finally! Someone who can drive at night!' So if anything, it does highlight that people look at Vice President Biden and his lack of mental sharpness and his age at potential inauguration.

RYAN PAYNE, PRESIDENT, PAYNE CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: I think the big thing is, sentiment can change on a dime and I think the thing that's being discounted here is by November, if you look at most economists, we're really going to be in a much better place than we are today in terms of where the economy is. And I think that's what's been discounted all summer so far, as most economists have been slightly dour on where we're going to be, but I think the surprises are going to continue to be in the positive. And that's something I've been saying for a long time that most people on Wall Street haven't.

So I think when you start thinking about November, you start thinking about a stronger economy. You start looking at the cases coming down for coronavirus on a daily basis because I think people are actually being more conscious about how they're living their life right now, especially in some of those states like Florida, Texas where they're having problems. I think the economy is going to be in a really, really good place and I think that's going to be really tough for Biden and Harris just because, let's face it, people vote with their wallet.

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is the Chairman of the RNC, Ronna McDaniel. Ronna, it's good to see you this morning, how does this change things?

In fact, Joe Biden, according to Kamala Harris was part of mass incarcerations for the black community.

President Trump gave funding to HBCUs, he created economic opportunities zones. He called an African-American journalist a junky. She's going to have to right some of the wrongs that the Biden campaign has committed and the gaffes that Joe Biden continually makes to the African-American community.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's pretty extraordinary when you think about some of those gaffes. Jonathan Madison, jump in here and as you -- I'd like to know if you agree with all of that, Jonathan, and as you jump in, let me just show you these latest numbers from Monmouth University, because they do show Joe Biden with a 10-point lead over President Trump nationwide, this is a slight improvement for the president, a previous Monmouth poll showed a 13-point gap between the two, Jonathan.

JONATHAN MADISON, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Absolutely, I mean, there are going to be some tough challenges ahead for both Biden and Kamala. So, you know, it's things like that, it's her prosecution record, and I think African-Americans kind of see her while she does have a great resume, she's done some great things, but as wanting to just garner the vote more than anything, it's about winning more than actually attending to African- Americans. And if there's anything we can take a lesson from, is that African-Americans are tired of being taken for granted and votes regardless of what party and what side you're on.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and, you know, Kevin McCarthy tweeted, Ronna that Kamala Harris would like to make the entire country like San Francisco. MCDANIEL: Yes, I don't think the middle of the country wants to see a California liberal telling us how to live. You look at California, it's a mess. I mean, she is a total radical. And I don't say tax and spend anymore, tax and bankrupt our country, Democrat.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. TikTok stealing user data. You know, we're talking about this on Sunday with Senator Tom Cotton who said that TikTok is like a Trojan horse on your phone, it vacuums up all your info.

Talk to us about the threat.

JONATHAN WARD, FOUNDER, ATLAS ORGANIZATION: Absolutely, good morning, Maria, it's great to be back. Well, I think what's important here is this executive orders that basically put, you know, pressure on two major Chinese technology companies, and on the one hand, TikTok and ByteDance, and on the other hand, WeChat and Tencent.

I mean, many people thought that the big tech companies in China were sort of good investments, you know, things to be pursuing for economic reasons, and of course, they're very closely linked to a Chinese state. I mean, you can't become a tech company on that scale without deep ties to the Chinese Communist Party. The other thing that matter is, you know, this week, the Fortune Global 500 was released, and there are now more Chinese companies on the Fortune Global 500 than U.S. companies.

So it's these corporations that are really China's economic battle fleet -- I mean, this is where we have to be focused as a country in order to win the competition with China. Every single one of them is tied to the party, many of them are state-owned. I mean, in this case ByteDance and you know, Tencent are not, but they're state affiliated. So, ultimately, America has a very robust toolkit for economic sanctions, economic containment and even economic warfare.

So, we're going to have to concentrate on these companies that are tied to the state, particularly those that are involved in surveillance in the civil-military fusion programs. You know, we can't let them into the U.S., so this all makes sense for us to do it, but we're also going to have a worldwide coalition that starts pushing back on China's companies.

BARTIROMO: Well, we'll see about that. I mean, right now, you've got Microsoft trying to convince government officials and the president that it's fine acquiring TikTok, and they can do what they need to do to eliminate any national security issue. But my question is how many people from TikTok are going to go work for Microsoft, Jonathan? Because we've seen over and over again, the Chinese Communist Party is able to steal from within, steal from the inside, whether it's those engineers from Motorola who were arrested years ago or the Cleveland Clinic or you know, the Harvard Charles Lieber, who was running the chemistry department.

They identify people or send people to America to get these incredible jobs, the CIA of CalPERS to steal information from the inside. Do you believe if a deal happens between these two companies, TikTok employees go work for Microsoft, Chinese nationals?

WARD: Well, this is going to be an important part of a deal. I mean, the technologies is going to have to be secured and it's going to have to be secured from insider threat. I mean, I think it does make sense for a U.S. company to take over TikTok if you can achieve all of that. But at the same time, what you can't do is allow, you know, Communist Party essentially, capabilities to continue within this technology, so that's what Microsoft has to be sure to fix.

BARTIROMO: Well, the behavior on the part of the CCP is just incredible, we've talked this week not just about the CCP military invading India, but now they're targeting islands in Japan, the Senkaku Islands, they, of course, overreached in Hong Kong. BARTIROMO: Right, and he was -- he was released on bail. Were you surprised by that apparently this morning?

WARD: I think the -- it's really -- they've made their message clear. I mean, they can detain anyone, they will detain the most prominent voices, and I'm sure they're -- you know, likely to do more if they -- if they think that he hasn't been silenced, so I think the story is not over.

urn:contentItem:5NFN-18V1-F03R-N0GP-00000-00Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Hits Another Record High Riding On Earnings2017-05-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisTesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Hits Another Record High Riding On EarningsMichelle Jones

May 01, 2017( ValueWalk: http://www.valuewalk.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Tesla Inc (TSLA) stock surged[1] by another 4% on Monday as investors anticipated the company's next earnings report, which is set for Wednesday after the bell. CEO Elon Musk's TED Talk probably also had something to do with it, given that he suggested that Tesla Inc (TSLA) drivers may soon be able to fall asleep at the wheel safely two years from now.

http://www.valuewalk.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Tesla_1485530978.jpgBlomst[2] / Pixabay Technician: buy Tesla stock ahead of earningsChart technician Todd Gordon of TradingAnalysis.com told CNBC[3]'s Trading Nation today that he likes how Tesla Inc (TSLA) stock is 'acting into earnings, and he feels that the record run is likely to continue for some time. He described Tesla Inc (TSLA) stock as moving upward in a 'parallel channel' starting in December. He explained that today's 3% increase helped Tesla Inc (TSLA) stock bust through what he said was a '$315 resistance.' He feels that the shares may rally on the company's earnings to reach the top line of that channel, if Wednesday's earnings report is in line with expectations. If the company meets expectations, he predicts that Tesla Inc (TSLA) stock could move toward $330. To capture the possibility of a strong week, Gordon bought a call spread consisting of buying the 320-strike call and selling the 325-strike call expiring on Friday. He'll see the biggest profit off this call spread if Tesla Inc (TSLA) stock ends this week at or above $325.Tesla stock also riding on Elon Musk's TED talkMuch of today's rally could be attributed to Musk's TED talk on Friday, in which he spoke on various topics, including Tesla Inc (TSLA)'s Autopilot system. The company has gotten a lot of flak[4] over Autopilot, but Musk claims that in 'about two years,' drivers will be able to sleep soundly at the wheel of their Tesla Inc (TSLA) when the vehicle sets off on a trip and wake up later when they reach their destination. That's a pretty tall order, and it's one that probably won't stand up to regulations because it seems very unlikely that in only two years, regulators will be ready to allow drivers to sleep while their car drives itself autonomously. Elon Musk also said that in November or December, they will show that a Tesla Inc (TSLA) vehicle will be able to make a trip from New York to Los Angeles entirely on Autopilot without any assistance from a driver. This is something he's been talking about for quite some time, and this could be more realistic. He also claims that the vehicle will be able to do this while also adjusting its own route in real time rather than having a route programmed in. Further, he claims that Autopilot will be able to adjust to a sudden destination change. Elon Musk's full TED talk is embedded at the end of this article.And Tesla's biggest competitor isIndeed, autonomous driving is arguably the hottest automotive niche right now, and it's so big that Morgan Stanley analyst and Tesla Inc (TSLA) stock perma-bull[5] Adam Jonas feels that the company's biggest competitor probably isn't other automakers. In a note dated April 28, Jonas — who still has his price target at $305 and rating at Overweight despite the run in the shares — highlighted the growing list of companies with permits to test autonomous vehicles in California. That list includes not only Tesla Inc (TSLA) and other automakers such as Volkswagen and Nissan, but also big tech names such as NVIDIA, Uber and Apple. He said the last eight permits issued by the California DMV were not auto firms, which demonstrates that it isn't just automakers with a stake in the autonomous driving[6] game. Tesla Inc (TSLA) stock soared to a record high of $327.25 during regular trading hours on Monday. Play Video[7]The post Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Hits Another Record High Riding On Earnings[8] appeared first on ValueWalk[9]. urn:contentItem:5VB7-K521-JCHV-V0JS-00000-00Tesla Is Decades Away From Full Self-Driving Cars2019-02-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisTesla Is Decades Away From Full Self-Driving CarsAnton Wahlman

If you are at 98% accuracy for autonomous driving right now, you are practically nowhere.

In my initial takedown of Tesla's December quarter report ---- I did not yet have the benefit of the conference call, which happened later. On the call last Wednesday, Tesla CEO Elon Musk talked about how far away we are from Level 5 autonomous driving, or even Level 4.

Here is what Musk said:

"So I guess like, I don't know, 98% good right now, but we need it to be like 99.999%, really extremely reliable. So - and the capability will be there for - when will we think it's safe for full self-driving? It's probably towards the end of this year, and then it's up to regulators to decide when they want to approve that."

If you are at 98% accuracy for autonomous driving right now, you are practically nowhere. In 100 seconds of driving, you will crash and possibly die, twice. A severely drunk person, or a five-year-old, would do a better job at driving safely. Dying within the first minute of the car driving you around, is not a selling point to the consumer.

Musk is right that you need to get to at least 99.999% for an autonomous car to be in the zone of reliability. Maybe it's more like 99.9999% or 99.99999%, but let's go with Musk's 99.999% for now, just to give him the benefit of the doubt.

The difference between 98% and 99.999 is huge. It's four orders of magnitude. It's something that will likely take at least 20 to 30 years to accomplish. We are simply not anywhere close today -- not Tesla, not anyone else.

Autonomous technologies will continue to improve, and help assist a driver in avoiding an accident if the driver makes a mistake, falls asleep, or has a heart attack. This will be very useful and helpful. All automakers are implementing such improvement, step by step, on ever-less expensive cars. Technologies available on sub-$25,000 cars today, were in many cases unavailable on $50,000 to $100,000 cars just three years ago.

However, "full self driving" in the sense of being Level 5 driverless, remains decades away. Try having a car follow directions from a cop waving his hands, to get around a stalled truck on a one-lane road, in a snowstorm. Or park in a field for a game during an off-road exercise.

Self-driving cars will have to be severely geo-fenced and weather-fenced, among other things. They may work at lower speeds in a low-complexity campus environment. But not in the real world, where they have to mix with all kinds of real traffic, unusual obstacles, and weather.

Elon Musk was right about needing to be at the 99.999% level of better. But by saying that Tesla is now at 98%, he admits that he is decades away from delivering what he is promising for already this year, 2019. He makes impossible promises.

________


At the time of submitting this article for publication, the author was short TSLA and long FCAU. However, positions can change at any time. The author regularly attends press conferences, new vehicle launches and equivalent, hosted by most major automakers.

urn:contentItem:5S17-DXP1-JD45-J17T-00000-00Tesla : le très cher poisson d'avril d'Elon Musk2018-04-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisTesla : le très cher poisson d'avril d'Elon MuskJean-Michel Bezat

Chronique. Les boursiers n'ont, décidément, pas d'humour et la blague d'Elon Musk lui a coûté plusieurs milliards de dollars. Toujours aussi déjanté, le patron du constructeur de voitures électriques haut de gamme (et de la société aérospatiale SpaceX) a voulu faire son «poisson», dimanche 1eravril. Il a posté ce Tweet: «Malgré d'intenses efforts pour trouver de l'argent, y compris une tentative désespérée de vente massive d'oeufs de Pâques, Tesla a fait totalement et complètement faillite. Une faillite telle que vous ne pouvez même pas l'imaginer». Il a aussi publié une photo de lui, un écriteau sur la poitrine, barré du mot «bankwupt» («ruiné»), assorti de ce commentaire: «Elon a été trouvé évanoui contre une Tesla Model 3, entouré de bouteilles «Teslaquilla», des traces de larmes séchées encore visibles sur ses joues.»

Ce n'était vraiment pas le moment, même si M. Musk est agacé par la chute de 20% de l'action Tesla à Wall Street depuis un mois. Le titre a encore plongé de 5,1%, lundi, à la Bourse de New York. Le constructeur traverse une passe industrielle et financière difficile: retards dans la production du dernier-né de sa gamme, le Model 3, et baisse annoncée de ses objectifs de ventes; rappel de 123000 Tesla S avant le week-end; enquête du régulateur américain des transports après un récent accident mortel impliquant un de ses véhicules autonomes, même si Tesla assure que le conducteur avait été dûment averti qu'il lui fallait reprendre le volant.

Fragile titan

Presque toutes les Big Tech sont sous surveillance des marchés, certains investisseurs estimant avoir trop de valeurs technologiques dans leur portefeuille. Et dans le collimateur des hommes politiques, aux Etats-Unis et en Europe: Amazon, cloué au pilori de Twitter par un Donald Trump accusant le géant du e-commerce de mettre la Poste américaine sous tension et de détruire le commerce traditionnel, y compris des enseignes historiques comme Toys'R'Us; Facebook, ébranlé par le scandale Cambridge Analytica, un pillage de 50millions de profils d'internautes au profit d'hommes politiques; Uber, lui aussi mis en cause après l'accident mortel causé par un de ses véhicules autonomes en Arizona. Nombre de ces sociétés ont ainsi vu fondre leur capitalisation ces dernières semaines.

Mais peu de titans de la Silicon Valley sont aussi fragiles que Tesla. Depuis sa création en2003, il n'a pas dégagé de bénéfices annuels. Sa dette est lourde et coûteuse, et il va encore devoir faire appel au marché pour se refinancer. L'avenir de la «maison Musk» repose donc sur la confiance d'investisseurs prêts à mettre ou remettre au pot pour continuer ce qui ressemble bien à une aventure. Et sans espérer que l'entreprise fasse des profits dans l'immédiat. Après tout, les actionnaires fidèles n'ont pas eu à se plaindre: l'action a gagné 515% en cinq ans. Ils attendent néanmoins avec impatience - et inquiétude - la publication du nouveau rythme de production du Model 3 dans quelques jours. Et là, le fantasque patron de Tesla n'aura pas droit au poisson d'avril.

urn:contentItem:5T0K-1TT1-DXH2-62WG-00000-00Tesla Likely To Face SEC Investigation Following Musk Tweets Amid Debate Of Market Manipulation; Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair; Uber, Lyft Hit Roadblock; Oscars Trims Telecast To 3 Hours, Adds Popular Film Award Category2018-08-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTMike Huckabee, Harvey PittNEWSDomestic080903cb.231Tesla Likely To Face SEC Investigation Following Musk Tweets Amid Debate Of Market Manipulation; Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair; Uber, Lyft Hit Roadblock; Oscars Trims Telecast To 3 Hours, Adds Popular Film Award CategoryMaria Bartiromo, James Freeman, Kristina Partsinevelos, Nicole Petallides, Gerri Willis, Stuart Varney, Gregg Jarrett, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Show me the money, that's the call to Tesla from Wall Street and Washington. The Securities and Exchange Commission reportedly launching a probe into Elon Musk's tweet about going private.

My interview with former SEC Chairman Harvey Pitt is coming up this morning to talk about that. Escalating trade tensions weighing on global investors. Futures edging higher this morning, Dow Industrials up 20 points. S&P 500 and the NASDAQ up just fractionally three points higher. This after a mixed performance yesterday on Wall Street, the NASDAQ was the gain top performer with the gain of four points on the session.

The Dow Industrials down 45 at the close yesterday. In Europe this morning, markets are mixed. Take a look at the European indices and we are looking at some pressure on stocks this morning, in Europe, as well. FT- 100 down 50 points, three quarters of one percent. The CAC quarante down a quarter of a percent, 15 points lower. And the DAX Index in Germany down 18 points.

BARTIROMO: Do you think there'll be any accountability here?

JARRETT: Not with Jeff Sessions and Rod Rosenstein at the helm of the Department of Justice. And that's a sad commentary on our system of justice right now. But Sessions is utterly feckless and Rosenstein, I think, is trying to continue to cover up his own wrongdoing. This is a guy who should have recused himself the moment he appointed Mueller. You can't be a prosecutor and a key witness all rolled into one.

BARTIROMO: Because he OK'd the fourth FISA warrant.

JARRETT: That's right. And you can only do that when you have new evidence. The best we can tell so far, they have no new evidence.

BARTIROMO: And there wasn't any evidence from the get-go, it was just the dossier.

JARRETT: That's right. And the FBI knew that the dossier was totally fabricated. You can read it online, I've read it a hundred times. I never failed to laugh. You know, it is the work of an amateur dime novelist in junior high school. And even Christopher Steele who wrote it, said, in court papers under oath in Great Britain, which I dug up, and it's in the book, that it's unverifiable because it was a guy who told a guy, who told the guy, who told me. Triple, quadruple hearsay based on anonymous sources. You can't use that sort of thing in a court of law. Get the FBI and DOJ, use it to gain a warrant to wiretap -- that's abuse of power to fraud on the court.

BARTIROMO: So, this is one political party spying on the -- on their opponent, there on the left.

JARRETT: Right. And where's the outrage over Hillary Clinton paying for all of this? Now, that is a violation of the law. The Trump Tower meeting, perfect legal. All the media has to do is read the federal campaign election act. Foreign nationals may participate in American political campaigns and providing any information is not a thing of value. But stonewalling to Congress is something I do not understand why it continues. They have a constitutional obligation to give Congress what it wants. And Congress should use the power of the purse and cut off the money.

BARTIROMO: Into the oversight agency.

JARRETT: That's the only way to have. Yes. Absolutely. But I blame Congress because for decades, whenever the Department of Justice and FBI didn't want to hand over documents, they just said we're not going to do it, and Congress never took action.

BARTIROMO: Right.

JARRETT: So, it's been habitual.

FREEMAN: Well, the President could order all of this declassified.

JARRETT: And he should. I think he is considering it, but you know, there are -- there are those advising him not to. He should absolutely order declassification of a FISA application documents, the Gang of Eight documents and the origin documents.

BARTIROMO: The American people have a right to know and they want to know. "The Russia Hoax," is the book, "The Illicit Scheme to Clear Hillary Clinton and Frame Donald Trump." Gregg Jarrett, thank you so much.

JARRETT: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Congrats on the book. Great to see you.

JARRETT: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We have breaking news right now we want to get to, Russian Foreign Ministry is saying this, Moscow will work on retaliatory measures in response to the new U.S. sanctions against Russia, it's according to Reuters this morning. The U.S. imposed new sanctions tied to the nerve agent poisoning of a former Russian spy and his daughter, that of course, breaking this week. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Uber and Lyft hitting a roadblock in New York City. The city council voted to limit the number of vehicles on the streets. Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in. Stu, good morning to you.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. You know, I think there's a backlash coming to this thing. As you say, the Mayor of New york is imposing a cap on the number of Uber and Lyft cars allowed in the city. In my opinion, that leaves a lot of wait times and to higher prices. But there's something else going on here, yellow cabs have often been accused (INAUDIBLE) regular taxicabs in New York City often accused of not picking up people of color because of their color. Uber has a way out.

Uber doesn't care what color you are, Uber doesn't care what your ethnicity is, they pick you up, it's all electronic. Well, that is going to be capped at the -- basically at the doings of the willing of the taxi industry. I think there's a backlash coming here from the minorities. Worse yet, I think there's going to be -- I think New York City will be used as a template as a test case for other cities in America and around the world, which want to fence in Uber, because they are devastating the local taxi industry. I think this is the wrong decision on so many levels, and I hope it's withdrawn, I don't think it will be but it should be.

BARTIROMO: Meaning there's a lot of backlash because, you know, look what happened to the taxis. The prices of the medallion plummeted.

VARNEY: Yes, the medallion was 2 -- was 1.3 million in 2013, and now it's between 160 and 250,000.

BARTIROMO: There you go.

VARNEY: That's a huge loss of capital for the taxi owners and this is their way of pushing back. But I think the pushback is very detrimental to many, many people.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll watch that. Stu, I know you'll have more on that in about 10 minutes. We'll see you then top of the hour "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins at 9:00 a.m. Eastern, right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart in the next few minutes. But first, overhauling the Oscars, details on the new changes coming to the Academy Awards including the addition of a popular film category, that's next.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: -- arts and sciences cutting the link to the show and introducing a category for outstanding achievement in popular film. Critics have complained that the broadcast is too long, too boring, too political, too condescending -- oh, maybe that's just my view.

Audiences would appear to agree, giving me telecast, its lowest ratings on record last February when a mere 26.5 million people tuned in. Remember, the Super Bowl got 107 million. Academy CEO Dawn Hudson said the board is, quote, committed to producing an entertaining show in three hours. Wow. Three -- it takes you three hours? The move was met with a frenzy of criticism, particularly from in the street journalists. Atlantic reporter David Sims called the (INAUDIBLE) award, the Black Panther memorial award for movie that were afraid won't get a big picture -- best picture nominations. Other called it lazy, ham-handed. In recent years, hit films like "Wonder Woman" have been snubbed by Oscar, although blockbusters from the past like "Gone With the Wind" were heavily recognized.

BARTIROMO: So, good changes?

WILLIS: Not the right changes necessary (INAUDIBLE) always a good idea. Can we do this in like 30 minutes or something?

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Three hours.

HUCKABEE: You can get a kidney replacement in less time and it's not as painful as watching the Oscars.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts on the changes.

PARTSINEVELOS: People like -- I remember when I was a kid, I used to love watching it because you'd never know who would win and you'd sit around together, and then the outfits, so I don't think that they're really going to shorten it that much, but they have lost viewership, for sure, because there's --

WILLIS: It's brutal. I always (INAUDIBLE) 4 million people every single night, OK? I mean, think about it.

PARTSINEVELOS: But also the performance. The performances and the actors and the comedians in between sets, those are -- that's pretty decent stuff, and sometimes there's controversy that comes out of it, so that's what I would watch for. I don't watch it, but --

WILLIS: I thought you'd see the fashion and would be happy. That's all I really need.

FREEMAN: I think beyond the suffocating politics, they just -- you have too many movies that almost no one in the television audience has seen so I understand what they're trying to do here. Maybe they ought to just recognize some of these films that a lot of Americans think were the best pictures: "American Sniper" -- I mean, most people would say that's a great movie, right?

WILLIS: Right. Well, this popcorn award, that's what they're trying to do.

BARTIROMO: The popular film.

WILLIS: Yes, popular film. But you know, that's sort of like a ghetto for popular -- you know, like, though, it should really win the major categories. You know what I mean? It should be elevated to the level of "Gone With the Wind," lots of very popular movies in previous years won those awards, not anymore.

FREEMAN: People don't watch the Oscars, though, because they want a political lecture that insults half of America. They want to -- they want to escape from all of that and have entertainment. When the celebrities go up there and lecture us and preach to us and point their fingers --

PARTSINEVELOS: They don't do that all the time during Oscars. I'm going to fight back against that. If you watch the full show --

BARTIROMO: It's become much more political.

PARTSINEVELOS: -- not all politics.

BARTIROMO: But it has become much more political.

HUCKABEE: It doesn't have to be all politics, but when all the politics they have is negative toward half the population, what happens? People say I'll watch paint dry before I'll sit here and watch this.

PARTSINEVELOS: There's always going to be something that's going to offend somebody out there, and usually, politics makes for good comedy.

HUCKABEE: But their ratings are tanking. It's not working. Maybe they should listen to us.

BARTIROMO: Gerri, good stuff.

WILLIS: I'm staying 30 minutes. I think I'm going to --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Coming up, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from our all-star panel right now. Governor Huckabee?

HUCKABEE: I want to say thanks to James Freeman for writing a book called "Borrowed Time," and giving really powerful insight into the financial crisis, I think it's a very, very important book, people need to read it, and I hope they will. James, I want it to be a bestseller.

FREEMAN: Thanks, Governor.

BARTIROMO: " Borrowed Time: Two Centuries of Booms, Busts, and Bailouts at Citi." Check out the book. Congratulations.

FREEMAN: I just want to say that the Governor is very handsome and very charming man.

(LAUGHTER)

FREEMAN: And a model American citizen.

BARTIROMO: Kristina?

PARTSINEVELOS: Well, I'm not going to -- I'm going to take a serious route just because we haven't been able to --

BARTIROMO: Hey, this is serious.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: This is serious stuff right here.

PARTSINEVELOS: You bring a wonderful book and you're a gorgeous man.

(CROSSTALK)

PARTSINEVELOS: Now, the timing just seems so awkward.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Tell us. This is an important story, too.

PARTSINEVELOS: This is an important story, but you guys are great. Saudi Arabia and Canada, the relations going on between both those countries, Canada foreign affairs minister tweeting about the human rights -- two human rights activists in Saudi. Saudi is saying, you can't tell us anything and what to do. So, I think that's just a big story, a big story.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll follow that. Kristina Partsinevelos, James Freeman, Mike Huckabee, great to see, everybody. Thank you so much. Great show, everybody. We'll see you again tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" is now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Hey, good morning, Maria. And good morning, everyone. August 9th, yes, mid-summer, dog days of summer, summer doldrums, not if --

urn:contentItem:5W31-4MJ1-JBHT-D3VS-00000-00Tesla Likely To Face SEC Investigation Following Musk Tweets Amid Debate Of Market Manipulation; Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair; Uber, Lyft Hit Roadblock; Oscars Trims Telecast To 3 Hours, Adds Popular Film Award Category2018-08-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:07ZLexisNexisTesla Likely To Face SEC Investigation Following Musk Tweets Amid Debate Of Market Manipulation; Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair; Uber, Lyft Hit Roadblock; Oscars Trims Telecast To 3 Hours, Adds Popular Film Award CategoryLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Show me the money, that's the call to Tesla from Wall Street and Washington. The Securities and Exchange Commission reportedly launching a probe into Elon Musk's tweet about going private.

My interview with former SEC Chairman Harvey Pitt is coming up this morning to talk about that. Escalating trade tensions weighing on global investors. Futures edging higher this morning, Dow Industrials up 20 points. S&P 500 and the NASDAQ up just fractionally three points higher. This after a mixed performance yesterday on Wall Street, the NASDAQ was the gain top performer with the gain of four points on the session.

The Dow Industrials down 45 at the close yesterday. In Europe this morning, markets are mixed. Take a look at the European indices and we are looking at some pressure on stocks this morning, in Europe, as well. FT- 100 down 50 points, three quarters of one percent. The CAC quarante down a quarter of a percent, 15 points lower. And the DAX Index in Germany down 18 points.

In Asia overnight, stocks finished mostly higher, the standout was China, Shanghai Composite up about two percent. A pair of merger deals dead. First up, Sinclair's takeover of Tribune has been called off this morning following recent comments from SEC Chairman Ajit Pai. Plus, the Rite-Aid and Albertson's deal also terminated. The company say investor pushback is to blame, that deal also off for now.

The media sector in focus. We are watching earnings from Viacom and 21st Century Fox. We are breaking down the numbers there. And as you can see both stocks are higher this morning. A front row seat to a natural disaster. Check out this unbelievable video taken on chairlift of a volcano erupting. And as you can see it, it's pretty extraordinary. Plus, this outfit is going viral this morning.

But Instagram user cannot figure out if it's a dress or is it a bikini. We report you decide. Let us know what you think. You send us tweet on that. All stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network Kristina Partsinevelos is with us, the Wall Street Journal's assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman is here and former Arkansas governor, Republican presidential candidate, Mike Huckabee.

Great to see you everybody this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FORMER ARKANSAS GOVERNOR: Good to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

HUCKABEE: Thanks.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Looking forward to your Harvey Pitt interview, makes sense of this Elon Musk tweets.

BARTIROMO: What do you think? What are the most important questions here?

FREEMAN: Well, it's funny. You think about these public statements being so careful and then he fires off what looked like very casual comments but I -- but I think it is a question. What does he need to show secure funding?

BARTIROMO: Right.

FREEMAN: And does this mean he's now obligated to bid for $120 now that he's teased it on Twitter.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And where is he going to get that money? I mean, who has that money to acquire and take the company private?

FREEMAN: Yes. Should be --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: It's $75 billion.

FREEMAN: Yes.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: What about --

FREEMAN: And Harvey is the guy to answer these questions.

PARTSINEVELOS: Institutional investors. So (INAUDIBLE) fact that their share stake is five percent, one of the largest after Elon Musk when you talk about insiding -- insiders and then you have five massive institutional accounts like T. Rowe, these guys have big part. So it's either going to be existing shareholders, institutional investors or some really rich guys from Silicon Valley.

HUCKABEE: Won't be me, let me just --

PARTSINEVELOS: Or sovereign wealth fund.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see. We know that the shorts certainly took a hit on that which is what he was intending. Our top story, Musk is under the microscope this morning. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Securities and Exchange Commission is in fact probing Elon Musk's tweet to find out if it was truthful. This after the Tesla CEO tweeted two o days ago this and considering taking Tesla private at $420 a share.

Funding secured and with that, the stock rallied. Joining me right now is former SEC Chairman Harvey Pitt. Great to see you, Harvey. Thanks so much for joining us.

HARVEY PITT, CHAIRMAN, SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION: Good to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What do you think as a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. What is the SEC looking at? Tell us where you see potential wrongdoing here.

PITT: Well, the entire announcement was highly problematic, and unprecedented and it's important to realize it's not the medium but it's the message. Going private transactions are usually announced in advance of the market opening or after the market closing. They're not announced in the middle day. Mr. Musk tweeted in the middle of the day. In addition it's not the CEO who announces this, but it is the board.

It's the company that makes this announcement. But here it was the CEO. What's more important is he stressed that he already had funding to pay $420 a share. But no efforts have yet been done to find out whether it's in the shareholders best interest to take the company private, and, if so, at what price, so all of this raises two fundamental questions. First, was he trying to artificially influence the price of the stock?

If he was that would be manipulation. Second, does he really have the money in hand? And is it binding commitment that would give him almost $70 billion in what would be at the largest going private transaction in U.S. history? That would be fraud if those things were not true.

BARTIROMO: OK. the SEC then needs to better understand what he was referring to when he said $420 and funding secured. Where would that money come from?

PITT: Well, it could come from either a consortium of banks, it could come from foreign sovereign investor. I mean -- the company did receive the big cash infusion from Saudi Arabia the day that earnings were announced this past week. So it's possible that that kind of money might exist. It's a large amount and it would take a great deal of effort to put it together. But it's not impossible.

BARTIROMO: Having said that, it's un-- it's unwise to be tweeting about this in middle of the day creating activity in the stock. Do you think the SEC is also looking at that given the fact that on the Saudi Arabia investment news, the stock gets rallied right before this announcement. It was up seven percent going into tweet and then up 11 percent after the tweet.

PITT: It's definitely the wrong way to do this kind of thing. It may not be per se illegal, but it is definitely highly problematic and it could be illegal depending on what his intentions were when he made the announcement.

BARTIROMO: So is there a deadline here, Harvey, in terms of when he would have to reveal his source of funding? I mean, if he says funding secured does the SEC want an answer now in terms of whether or not it's secured and how long does he have to come up with whatever deal he was referring to?

PITT: No. I think he is required to demonstrate that at the time of his tweet he already had a legally binding commitment for $420 a share.
