GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: -- arts and sciences cutting the link to the show and introducing a category for outstanding achievement in popular film. Critics have complained that the broadcast is too long, too boring, too political, too condescending -- oh, maybe that's just my view.

Audiences would appear to agree, giving me telecast, its lowest ratings on record last February when a mere 26.5 million people tuned in. Remember, the Super Bowl got 107 million. Academy CEO Dawn Hudson said the board is, quote, committed to producing an entertaining show in three hours. Wow. Three -- it takes you three hours? The move was met with a frenzy of criticism, particularly from in the street journalists. Atlantic reporter David Sims called the (INAUDIBLE) award, the Black Panther memorial award for movie that were afraid won't get a big picture -- best picture nominations. Other called it lazy, ham-handed. In recent years, hit films like "Wonder Woman" have been snubbed by Oscar, although blockbusters from the past like "Gone With the Wind" were heavily recognized.

BARTIROMO: So, good changes?

WILLIS: Not the right changes necessary (INAUDIBLE) always a good idea. Can we do this in like 30 minutes or something?

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Three hours.

HUCKABEE: You can get a kidney replacement in less time and it's not as painful as watching the Oscars.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts on the changes.

PARTSINEVELOS: People like -- I remember when I was a kid, I used to love watching it because you'd never know who would win and you'd sit around together, and then the outfits, so I don't think that they're really going to shorten it that much, but they have lost viewership, for sure, because there's --

WILLIS: It's brutal. I always (INAUDIBLE) 4 million people every single night, OK? I mean, think about it.

PARTSINEVELOS: But also the performance. The performances and the actors and the comedians in between sets, those are -- that's pretty decent stuff, and sometimes there's controversy that comes out of it, so that's what I would watch for. I don't watch it, but --

WILLIS: I thought you'd see the fashion and would be happy. That's all I really need.

FREEMAN: I think beyond the suffocating politics, they just -- you have too many movies that almost no one in the television audience has seen so I understand what they're trying to do here. Maybe they ought to just recognize some of these films that a lot of Americans think were the best pictures: "American Sniper" -- I mean, most people would say that's a great movie, right?

WILLIS: Right. Well, this popcorn award, that's what they're trying to do.

BARTIROMO: The popular film.

WILLIS: Yes, popular film. But you know, that's sort of like a ghetto for popular -- you know, like, though, it should really win the major categories. You know what I mean? It should be elevated to the level of "Gone With the Wind," lots of very popular movies in previous years won those awards, not anymore.

FREEMAN: People don't watch the Oscars, though, because they want a political lecture that insults half of America. They want to -- they want to escape from all of that and have entertainment. When the celebrities go up there and lecture us and preach to us and point their fingers --

PARTSINEVELOS: They don't do that all the time during Oscars. I'm going to fight back against that. If you watch the full show --

BARTIROMO: It's become much more political.

PARTSINEVELOS: -- not all politics.

BARTIROMO: But it has become much more political.

HUCKABEE: It doesn't have to be all politics, but when all the politics they have is negative toward half the population, what happens? People say I'll watch paint dry before I'll sit here and watch this.

PARTSINEVELOS: There's always going to be something that's going to offend somebody out there, and usually, politics makes for good comedy.

HUCKABEE: But their ratings are tanking. It's not working. Maybe they should listen to us.

BARTIROMO: Gerri, good stuff.

WILLIS: I'm staying 30 minutes. I think I'm going to --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Coming up, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from our all-star panel right now. Governor Huckabee?

HUCKABEE: I want to say thanks to James Freeman for writing a book called "Borrowed Time," and giving really powerful insight into the financial crisis, I think it's a very, very important book, people need to read it, and I hope they will. James, I want it to be a bestseller.

FREEMAN: Thanks, Governor.

BARTIROMO: " Borrowed Time: Two Centuries of Booms, Busts, and Bailouts at Citi." Check out the book. Congratulations.

FREEMAN: I just want to say that the Governor is very handsome and very charming man.

(LAUGHTER)

FREEMAN: And a model American citizen.

BARTIROMO: Kristina?

PARTSINEVELOS: Well, I'm not going to -- I'm going to take a serious route just because we haven't been able to --

BARTIROMO: Hey, this is serious.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: This is serious stuff right here.

PARTSINEVELOS: You bring a wonderful book and you're a gorgeous man.

(CROSSTALK)

PARTSINEVELOS: Now, the timing just seems so awkward.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Tell us. This is an important story, too.

PARTSINEVELOS: This is an important story, but you guys are great. Saudi Arabia and Canada, the relations going on between both those countries, Canada foreign affairs minister tweeting about the human rights -- two human rights activists in Saudi. Saudi is saying, you can't tell us anything and what to do. So, I think that's just a big story, a big story.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll follow that. Kristina Partsinevelos, James Freeman, Mike Huckabee, great to see, everybody. Thank you so much. Great show, everybody. We'll see you again tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" is now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Hey, good morning, Maria. And good morning, everyone. August 9th, yes, mid-summer, dog days of summer, summer doldrums, not if --

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T0Y-CMV1-JBHT-D04W-00000-00Tesla Likely To Face SEC Investigation Following Musk Tweets Amid Debate Of Market Manipulation; Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair; Uber, Lyft Hit Roadblock; Oscars Trims Telecast To 3 Hours, Adds Popular Film Award Category2018-08-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisTesla Likely To Face SEC Investigation Following Musk Tweets Amid Debate Of Market Manipulation; Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair; Uber, Lyft Hit Roadblock; Oscars Trims Telecast To 3 Hours, Adds Popular Film Award CategoryLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Show me the money, that's the call to Tesla from Wall Street and Washington. The Securities and Exchange Commission reportedly launching a probe into Elon Musk's tweet about going private.

My interview with former SEC Chairman Harvey Pitt is coming up this morning to talk about that. Escalating trade tensions weighing on global investors. Futures edging higher this morning, Dow Industrials up 20 points. S&P 500 and the NASDAQ up just fractionally three points higher. This after a mixed performance yesterday on Wall Street, the NASDAQ was the gain top performer with the gain of four points on the session.

The Dow Industrials down 45 at the close yesterday. In Europe this morning, markets are mixed. Take a look at the European indices and we are looking at some pressure on stocks this morning, in Europe, as well. FT- 100 down 50 points, three quarters of one percent. The CAC quarante down a quarter of a percent, 15 points lower. And the DAX Index in Germany down 18 points.

In Asia overnight, stocks finished mostly higher, the standout was China, Shanghai Composite up about two percent. A pair of merger deals dead. First up, Sinclair's takeover of Tribune has been called off this morning following recent comments from SEC Chairman Ajit Pai. Plus, the Rite-Aid and Albertson's deal also terminated. The company say investor pushback is to blame, that deal also off for now.

The media sector in focus. We are watching earnings from Viacom and 21st Century Fox. We are breaking down the numbers there. And as you can see both stocks are higher this morning. A front row seat to a natural disaster. Check out this unbelievable video taken on chairlift of a volcano erupting. And as you can see it, it's pretty extraordinary. Plus, this outfit is going viral this morning.

But Instagram user cannot figure out if it's a dress or is it a bikini. We report you decide. Let us know what you think. You send us tweet on that. All stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network Kristina Partsinevelos is with us, the Wall Street Journal's assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman is here and former Arkansas governor, Republican presidential candidate, Mike Huckabee.

Great to see you everybody this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FORMER ARKANSAS GOVERNOR: Good to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

HUCKABEE: Thanks.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Looking forward to your Harvey Pitt interview, makes sense of this Elon Musk tweets.

BARTIROMO: What do you think? What are the most important questions here?

FREEMAN: Well, it's funny. You think about these public statements being so careful and then he fires off what looked like very casual comments but I -- but I think it is a question. What does he need to show secure funding?

BARTIROMO: Right.

FREEMAN: And does this mean he's now obligated to bid for $120 now that he's teased it on Twitter.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And where is he going to get that money? I mean, who has that money to acquire and take the company private?

FREEMAN: Yes. Should be --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: It's $75 billion.

FREEMAN: Yes.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: What about --

FREEMAN: And Harvey is the guy to answer these questions.

PARTSINEVELOS: Institutional investors. So (INAUDIBLE) fact that their share stake is five percent, one of the largest after Elon Musk when you talk about insiding -- insiders and then you have five massive institutional accounts like T. Rowe, these guys have big part. So it's either going to be existing shareholders, institutional investors or some really rich guys from Silicon Valley.

HUCKABEE: Won't be me, let me just --

PARTSINEVELOS: Or sovereign wealth fund.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see. We know that the shorts certainly took a hit on that which is what he was intending. Our top story, Musk is under the microscope this morning. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Securities and Exchange Commission is in fact probing Elon Musk's tweet to find out if it was truthful. This after the Tesla CEO tweeted two o days ago this and considering taking Tesla private at $420 a share.

Funding secured and with that, the stock rallied. Joining me right now is former SEC Chairman Harvey Pitt. Great to see you, Harvey. Thanks so much for joining us.

HARVEY PITT, CHAIRMAN, SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION: Good to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What do you think as a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. What is the SEC looking at? Tell us where you see potential wrongdoing here.

PITT: Well, the entire announcement was highly problematic, and unprecedented and it's important to realize it's not the medium but it's the message. Going private transactions are usually announced in advance of the market opening or after the market closing. They're not announced in the middle day. Mr. Musk tweeted in the middle of the day. In addition it's not the CEO who announces this, but it is the board.

It's the company that makes this announcement. But here it was the CEO. What's more important is he stressed that he already had funding to pay $420 a share. But no efforts have yet been done to find out whether it's in the shareholders best interest to take the company private, and, if so, at what price, so all of this raises two fundamental questions. First, was he trying to artificially influence the price of the stock?

If he was that would be manipulation. Second, does he really have the money in hand? And is it binding commitment that would give him almost $70 billion in what would be at the largest going private transaction in U.S. history? That would be fraud if those things were not true.

BARTIROMO: OK. the SEC then needs to better understand what he was referring to when he said $420 and funding secured. Where would that money come from?

PITT: Well, it could come from either a consortium of banks, it could come from foreign sovereign investor. I mean -- the company did receive the big cash infusion from Saudi Arabia the day that earnings were announced this past week. So it's possible that that kind of money might exist. It's a large amount and it would take a great deal of effort to put it together. But it's not impossible.

BARTIROMO: Having said that, it's un-- it's unwise to be tweeting about this in middle of the day creating activity in the stock. Do you think the SEC is also looking at that given the fact that on the Saudi Arabia investment news, the stock gets rallied right before this announcement. It was up seven percent going into tweet and then up 11 percent after the tweet.

PITT: It's definitely the wrong way to do this kind of thing. It may not be per se illegal, but it is definitely highly problematic and it could be illegal depending on what his intentions were when he made the announcement.

BARTIROMO: So is there a deadline here, Harvey, in terms of when he would have to reveal his source of funding? I mean, if he says funding secured does the SEC want an answer now in terms of whether or not it's secured and how long does he have to come up with whatever deal he was referring to?

PITT: No. I think he is required to demonstrate that at the time of his tweet he already had a legally binding commitment for $420 a share. That would be the requirement, so the SEC can request or subpoena documents asking for proof as to what his financing was and what the legal basis was for his suggestion that it was secured which is a very strong term.

BARTIROMO: Very strong term. What's the penalty, Harvey, if Musk was just -- I don't want to say lying but coming up with an idea that perhaps wasn't necessarily intact funding secured, what's the penalty?

PITT: Well, we don't of course know if the facts are yet but the penalties are quite serious. If he committed fraud or manipulated the market, he would be liable both civilly for an extreme amount of damages but also he could have potential criminal liability as well.

BARTIROMO: Why criminal?

PITT: Because almost every violation of the Federal securities laws is both a civil problem that the SEC pursues and also a potential criminal issue that the Department of Justice pursues.

BARTIROMO: I see. And so when do you expect we'll hear more about this? I mean, for example, when are we going to better -- have a clearer idea whether or not there was in fact funding in place?

PITT: I would believe that the next set of announcements will come at some point from Tesla itself. The company will probably organize a special committee of independent directors who will then indicate exactly where matters stand and whether they are going to pursue Musk's suggest that the company go private. I don't think we will hear from the SEC until it has completed its investigation.

BARTIROMO: What about shareholder lawsuits, Harvey, are you expecting that to also be an issue here? Because I know that the short sellers loss at lot of money on that as the stock went up and that's basically what I assumed Elon Musk wanted to do because he's been sticking it to shorts and he's, you know, uncomfortable with some of the criticism that the company has received.

You saw a very upsetting conference call recently where he pushed back on some of the criticism and the short sellers questioning about his burn rate, how much cash is he burning? So, are you expecting shareholder lawsuits?

PITT: I think they are inevitable. It's just a matter of time before lawsuits are filed because of the enormous fluctuation in the price of the stock. I would think the shorts will bring a lawsuit against Mr. Musk and Tesla.

BARTIROMO: Is there any precedence here, Harvey? Have you ever seen something like this before?

PITT: I've never seen anything like this kind of announcement. I have seen short sellers, sue certainly companies and I have certainly seen companies sue short sellers. It's a fact of life that if you're public, you're going to get criticism and the shorts are people you just have to live with.

BARTIROMO: Right. And, obviously, that's what they are doing. They're critical of the company. They're shorting the stock. I mean, that's why they exist. So you're expecting the SEC to be asking questions about the funding. Any other questions coming from the SEC in your view?

PITT: Well, I think they will look into why the board didn't make an announcement sooner, why they waited for Mr. Musk to go for -- forward, and I think they will also try to determine what kinds of behind-the-scenes activities were taken by the company.

BARTIROMO: So in other words, background because the board is saying yes, Harvey Pitt, the board is saying yes, that Elon Musk has discussed the potential of going private with us before. But there is no mention of any $420 price.

PITT: No. And where that price comes from is very hard to understand. It may be a very good price, but in terms of an economic analysis it may turn out that it's not as good a price as should be paid for this company.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly. I mean, when you're talking about $420 a share, that's like $70 billion, right? $75 billion?

PITT: Yes. And unprecedented amount of money, it truly is.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Harvey, it's great to see you again. Hope you'll come back soon. Thanks so much for your insights this morning.

PITT: Sure. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Harvey Pitt joining us there. And we'll take a short break. When we come back. The Tribune Media-Sinclair deal is dead. Tribune says that the $3.9 deal can no longer move forward after comments from SEC Chairman Ajit Pai. The latest coming up there. Then half dress, half bikini? The new dress causing confusion online. That's coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Tribute Media called off its buyout by Sinclair Broadcast Group. Cheryl Casone with the details. Two deals that are dead today, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We got two deals, that is right, Maria. First to Tribune, they've terminated their $3.9-billion deal and they're suing Sinclair for breach of contract for not doing enough to win approval from regulators. You may remember last month, SEC Chairman Ajit Pai said he had serious concerns about the merger. Take a look at the stocks, shares of Sinclair right now, they are lower in the premarket trading.

Down more than three percent. Tribune Media, not really trading it but shares down more than 20 percent so far this year. So two stocks to watch now. We're also watching shares of Rite-Aid right now. The stock plunging more than 10 percent in the premarket. The sell-off coming after Rite-Aid and Albertsons called off their $24 billion merger. Some big Rite-Aid shareholders plan to vote against the deal today.

Rite-Aid and Albertsons wanted to team up in order to compete better against CBS, Walgreens and potentially as you know Amazon has been trying to get into the pharmaceutical business as well.

All right. Check this out. A volcanic eruption in Chile gets a rider on a ski list, the front row seat to the action all on tape. The eruption shot up a 5,000 foot column of dust and ash as he was filming all of this with his cell phone. This comes from a volcano complex that's in the Andes Mountain but pretty incredible pictures and pretty close.

And finally there is this. We've seen some pretty weird fashion trends in the last year, upside down shorts, plastic jeans. Well, here is a new one. This is a bikini and it's a dress, all in one. This comes from the fashion brand, PrettyLittleThing. And after having one of their models wear it on Instagram picture, people started to freak out.

There it is. We'll let you decide. Looks like she couldn't decide on what to wear so she cut both in half and sewed them together. Maybe. Here's another comment. She's going to dinner, clubbing and swimming all at once. Yes. The whole thing goes for $35.00 maybe. Maria, you could wear it with some crack heels? You know.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: That would be an interesting pairing.

BARTIROMO: Sure would. So is it a -- is it a dress or is it a bikini?

CASONE: It's both.

BARTIROMO: It's both.

CASONE: Yes. Because --

PARTSINEVELOS: Why not have both?

BARTIROMO: You're getting your money for it.

PARTSINEVELOS: Remember the black or blue dress or is it blue or white dress?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PARTSINEVELOS: Same thing. But I know about you. I think, Governor, it would look better own you with man-bun, crack heels.

HUCKABEE: Pretty sure it wouldn't.

FREEMAN: Going to be strong with the man-bun. Yes.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You got to really loving this man-bun.

HUCKABEE: -- I would feel naked. Oh.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T0Y-CMV1-JBHT-D04T-00000-00Tesla Likely To Face SEC Investigation Following Musk Tweets Amid Debate Of Market Manipulation; Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair; Uber, Lyft Hit Roadblock; Oscars Trims Telecast To 3 Hours, Adds Popular Film Award Category2018-08-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:07ZLexisNexisTesla Likely To Face SEC Investigation Following Musk Tweets Amid Debate Of Market Manipulation; Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair; Uber, Lyft Hit Roadblock; Oscars Trims Telecast To 3 Hours, Adds Popular Film Award CategoryLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Show me the money, that's the call to Tesla from Wall Street and Washington. The Securities and Exchange Commission reportedly launching a probe into Elon Musk's tweet about going private.

My interview with former SEC Chairman Harvey Pitt is coming up this morning to talk about that. Escalating trade tensions weighing on global investors. Futures edging higher this morning, Dow Industrials up 20 points. S&P 500 and the NASDAQ up just fractionally three points higher. This after a mixed performance yesterday on Wall Street, the NASDAQ was the gain top performer with the gain of four points on the session.

The Dow Industrials down 45 at the close yesterday. In Europe this morning, markets are mixed. Take a look at the European indices and we are looking at some pressure on stocks this morning, in Europe, as well. FT- 100 down 50 points, three quarters of one percent. The CAC quarante down a quarter of a percent, 15 points lower. And the DAX Index in Germany down 18 points.

In Asia overnight, stocks finished mostly higher, the standout was China, Shanghai Composite up about two percent. A pair of merger deals dead. First up, Sinclair's takeover of Tribune has been called off this morning following recent comments from SEC Chairman Ajit Pai. Plus, the Rite-Aid and Albertson's deal also terminated. The company say investor pushback is to blame, that deal also off for now.

The media sector in focus. We are watching earnings from Viacom and 21st Century Fox. We are breaking down the numbers there. And as you can see both stocks are higher this morning. A front row seat to a natural disaster. Check out this unbelievable video taken on chairlift of a volcano erupting. And as you can see it, it's pretty extraordinary. Plus, this outfit is going viral this morning.

But Instagram user cannot figure out if it's a dress or is it a bikini. We report you decide. Let us know what you think. You send us tweet on that. All stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network Kristina Partsinevelos is with us, the Wall Street Journal's assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman is here and former Arkansas governor, Republican presidential candidate, Mike Huckabee.

Great to see you everybody this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FORMER ARKANSAS GOVERNOR: Good to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

HUCKABEE: Thanks.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Looking forward to your Harvey Pitt interview, makes sense of this Elon Musk tweets.

BARTIROMO: What do you think? What are the most important questions here?

FREEMAN: Well, it's funny. You think about these public statements being so careful and then he fires off what looked like very casual comments but I -- but I think it is a question. What does he need to show secure funding?

BARTIROMO: Right.

FREEMAN: And does this mean he's now obligated to bid for $120 now that he's teased it on Twitter.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And where is he going to get that money? I mean, who has that money to acquire and take the company private?

FREEMAN: Yes. Should be --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: It's $75 billion.

FREEMAN: Yes.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: What about --

FREEMAN: And Harvey is the guy to answer these questions.

PARTSINEVELOS: Institutional investors. So (INAUDIBLE) fact that their share stake is five percent, one of the largest after Elon Musk when you talk about insiding -- insiders and then you have five massive institutional accounts like T. Rowe, these guys have big part. So it's either going to be existing shareholders, institutional investors or some really rich guys from Silicon Valley.

HUCKABEE: Won't be me, let me just --

PARTSINEVELOS: Or sovereign wealth fund.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see. We know that the shorts certainly took a hit on that which is what he was intending. Our top story, Musk is under the microscope this morning. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Securities and Exchange Commission is in fact probing Elon Musk's tweet to find out if it was truthful. This after the Tesla CEO tweeted two o days ago this and considering taking Tesla private at $420 a share.

Funding secured and with that, the stock rallied. Joining me right now is former SEC Chairman Harvey Pitt. Great to see you, Harvey. Thanks so much for joining us.

HARVEY PITT, CHAIRMAN, SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION: Good to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What do you think as a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. What is the SEC looking at? Tell us where you see potential wrongdoing here.

PITT: Well, the entire announcement was highly problematic, and unprecedented and it's important to realize it's not the medium but it's the message. Going private transactions are usually announced in advance of the market opening or after the market closing. They're not announced in the middle day. Mr. Musk tweeted in the middle of the day. In addition it's not the CEO who announces this, but it is the board.

It's the company that makes this announcement. But here it was the CEO. What's more important is he stressed that he already had funding to pay $420 a share. But no efforts have yet been done to find out whether it's in the shareholders best interest to take the company private, and, if so, at what price, so all of this raises two fundamental questions. First, was he trying to artificially influence the price of the stock?

If he was that would be manipulation. Second, does he really have the money in hand? And is it binding commitment that would give him almost $70 billion in what would be at the largest going private transaction in U.S. history? That would be fraud if those things were not true.

BARTIROMO: OK. the SEC then needs to better understand what he was referring to when he said $420 and funding secured. Where would that money come from?

PITT: Well, it could come from either a consortium of banks, it could come from foreign sovereign investor. I mean -- the company did receive the big cash infusion from Saudi Arabia the day that earnings were announced this past week. So it's possible that that kind of money might exist. It's a large amount and it would take a great deal of effort to put it together. But it's not impossible.

BARTIROMO: Having said that, it's un-- it's unwise to be tweeting about this in middle of the day creating activity in the stock. Do you think the SEC is also looking at that given the fact that on the Saudi Arabia investment news, the stock gets rallied right before this announcement. It was up seven percent going into tweet and then up 11 percent after the tweet.

PITT: It's definitely the wrong way to do this kind of thing. It may not be per se illegal, but it is definitely highly problematic and it could be illegal depending on what his intentions were when he made the announcement.

BARTIROMO: So is there a deadline here, Harvey, in terms of when he would have to reveal his source of funding? I mean, if he says funding secured does the SEC want an answer now in terms of whether or not it's secured and how long does he have to come up with whatever deal he was referring to?

PITT: No. I think he is required to demonstrate that at the time of his tweet he already had a legally binding commitment for $420 a share. That would be the requirement, so the SEC can request or subpoena documents asking for proof as to what his financing was and what the legal basis was for his suggestion that it was secured which is a very strong term.

BARTIROMO: Very strong term. What's the penalty, Harvey, if Musk was just -- I don't want to say lying but coming up with an idea that perhaps wasn't necessarily intact funding secured, what's the penalty?

PITT: Well, we don't of course know if the facts are yet but the penalties are quite serious. If he committed fraud or manipulated the market, he would be liable both civilly for an extreme amount of damages but also he could have potential criminal liability as well.

BARTIROMO: Why criminal?

PITT: Because almost every violation of the Federal securities laws is both a civil problem that the SEC pursues and also a potential criminal issue that the Department of Justice pursues.

BARTIROMO: I see. And so when do you expect we'll hear more about this? I mean, for example, when are we going to better -- have a clearer idea whether or not there was in fact funding in place?

PITT: I would believe that the next set of announcements will come at some point from Tesla itself. The company will probably organize a special committee of independent directors who will then indicate exactly where matters stand and whether they are going to pursue Musk's suggest that the company go private. I don't think we will hear from the SEC until it has completed its investigation.

BARTIROMO: What about shareholder lawsuits, Harvey, are you expecting that to also be an issue here? Because I know that the short sellers loss at lot of money on that as the stock went up and that's basically what I assumed Elon Musk wanted to do because he's been sticking it to shorts and he's, you know, uncomfortable with some of the criticism that the company has received.

You saw a very upsetting conference call recently where he pushed back on some of the criticism and the short sellers questioning about his burn rate, how much cash is he burning? So, are you expecting shareholder lawsuits?

PITT: I think they are inevitable. It's just a matter of time before lawsuits are filed because of the enormous fluctuation in the price of the stock. I would think the shorts will bring a lawsuit against Mr. Musk and Tesla.

BARTIROMO: Is there any precedence here, Harvey? Have you ever seen something like this before?

PITT: I've never seen anything like this kind of announcement. I have seen short sellers, sue certainly companies and I have certainly seen companies sue short sellers. It's a fact of life that if you're public, you're going to get criticism and the shorts are people you just have to live with.

BARTIROMO: Right. And, obviously, that's what they are doing. They're critical of the company. They're shorting the stock. I mean, that's why they exist. So you're expecting the SEC to be asking questions about the funding. Any other questions coming from the SEC in your view?

PITT: Well, I think they will look into why the board didn't make an announcement sooner, why they waited for Mr. Musk to go for -- forward, and I think they will also try to determine what kinds of behind-the-scenes activities were taken by the company.

BARTIROMO: So in other words, background because the board is saying yes, Harvey Pitt, the board is saying yes, that Elon Musk has discussed the potential of going private with us before. But there is no mention of any $420 price.

PITT: No. And where that price comes from is very hard to understand. It may be a very good price, but in terms of an economic analysis it may turn out that it's not as good a price as should be paid for this company.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly. I mean, when you're talking about $420 a share, that's like $70 billion, right? $75 billion?

PITT: Yes. And unprecedented amount of money, it truly is.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Harvey, it's great to see you again. Hope you'll come back soon. Thanks so much for your insights this morning.

PITT: Sure. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Harvey Pitt joining us there. And we'll take a short break. When we come back. The Tribune Media-Sinclair deal is dead. Tribune says that the $3.9 deal can no longer move forward after comments from SEC Chairman Ajit Pai. The latest coming up there. Then half dress, half bikini? The new dress causing confusion online. That's coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Tribute Media called off its buyout by Sinclair Broadcast Group. Cheryl Casone with the details. Two deals that are dead today, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We got two deals, that is right, Maria. First to Tribune, they've terminated their $3.9-billion deal and they're suing Sinclair for breach of contract for not doing enough to win approval from regulators. You may remember last month, SEC Chairman Ajit Pai said he had serious concerns about the merger. Take a look at the stocks, shares of Sinclair right now, they are lower in the premarket trading.

Down more than three percent. Tribune Media, not really trading it but shares down more than 20 percent so far this year. So two stocks to watch now. We're also watching shares of Rite-Aid right now. The stock plunging more than 10 percent in the premarket. The sell-off coming after Rite-Aid and Albertsons called off their $24 billion merger. Some big Rite-Aid shareholders plan to vote against the deal today.

Rite-Aid and Albertsons wanted to team up in order to compete better against CBS, Walgreens and potentially as you know Amazon has been trying to get into the pharmaceutical business as well.

All right. Check this out. A volcanic eruption in Chile gets a rider on a ski list, the front row seat to the action all on tape. The eruption shot up a 5,000 foot column of dust and ash as he was filming all of this with his cell phone. This comes from a volcano complex that's in the Andes Mountain but pretty incredible pictures and pretty close.

And finally there is this. We've seen some pretty weird fashion trends in the last year, upside down shorts, plastic jeans. Well, here is a new one. This is a bikini and it's a dress, all in one. This comes from the fashion brand, PrettyLittleThing. And after having one of their models wear it on Instagram picture, people started to freak out.

There it is. We'll let you decide. Looks like she couldn't decide on what to wear so she cut both in half and sewed them together. Maybe. Here's another comment. She's going to dinner, clubbing and swimming all at once. Yes. The whole thing goes for $35.00 maybe. Maria, you could wear it with some crack heels? You know.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: That would be an interesting pairing.

BARTIROMO: Sure would. So is it a -- is it a dress or is it a bikini?

CASONE: It's both.

BARTIROMO: It's both.

CASONE: Yes. Because --

PARTSINEVELOS: Why not have both?

BARTIROMO: You're getting your money for it.

PARTSINEVELOS: Remember the black or blue dress or is it blue or white dress?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PARTSINEVELOS: Same thing. But I know about you. I think, Governor, it would look better own you with man-bun, crack heels.

HUCKABEE: Pretty sure it wouldn't.

FREEMAN: Going to be strong with the man-bun. Yes.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You got to really loving this man-bun.

HUCKABEE: -- I would feel naked. Oh.

FREEMAN: If I wear that without the man-bun I would just feel just naked.

HUCKABEE: You thought of either of us wearing that is something that there are television sets across America that are going to be off mode.

BARTIROMO: No.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: We don't want that. We don't want that. Coming up. Viacom is reporting quarterly earnings this morning. We're breaking down those numbers coming up next. Big week for media. Then overhauling the Oscars. Details on new changes coming to the academy awards quarterly including the addition of a popular film category, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Both parent company of the Fox Business Network, 21st Century Fox quarterly profit nearly doubled due to cable and film strength. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange watching the stock and the overall market this morning. Nic, good morning to you.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. So we talked about 21st Century Fox, our parent and it beat on top and bottom line. The analyst have to optimism there as you noted in those particular areas and that's exactly what came. In fact it did better than expected. Deadpool 2, the strength of Fox News just among the reasons why we did see it beat the 18 percent year over year.

Revenue increase, strong double-digit growth across all the segments and the new and obviously what happened, the transaction, Disney and the new Fox transactions, that -- they say unlocked enormous shareholder value. In fact when you take a look at the stock over the fiscal year it's about 75 percent gain, that clearly outpaces the S&P 500. And the media group which actually has declined over that period.

Of course, there's still locked in the -- in the bidding war with CMSCA and that would be Comcast, but --

BARTIROMO: Yes. You check that?

PETALLIDES: We'll watch that. So that is the big difference. Also, last but not least, we're taking a look at Viacom this morning and that came in profit top revenue fell and there was the slump in ad sales which fell short. And that number which I did talk about the increased shareholder value I did get from the 21st Century Fox headlines themselves. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic. Thank you so much. Nicole, we'll be watching all of that. Switching gears to the censorship of conservatives on social media. It has the attention of lawmakers now including House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy who talked to us about this as well as House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes who want - both want answers on action. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: I want to see bias stop, especially going after conservatives. I mean, just look at three points that showed up in Google right before the primary election in California. The party of Lincoln, the party of Reagan, that's not what it said, it said Nazism.

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), CHAIRMAN, SENATE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: I don't know what Twitter is up to. It sure looks to me like they're censoring people and they ought -- they ought to stop it and we're looking at any legal remedies that we can go through.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: All right. So that was Devin Nunes and Kevin McCarthy. Kevin McCarthy was talking about remember right before the primary elections in California. You Googled GOP California and in the search results got Naziism. Your thoughts, Governor. I know this is an important topic to you.

HUCKABEE: Well, it really is an important topic. We talk about Russian interference. I'm worried about social media interference. How are they manipulating elections, how are they manipulating the information and the question comes as somebody who doesn't really like government regulation and intervention, we're headed there.

We're going to get it because social media platforms are no longer just social media where people chit-chat about their yoga classes and their daughter's wedding, they're now the place where people get news, they are public utilities just like electricity, water, cable television and telephone. And so government is going to step in at some point. I think sooner than later and they're going to regulate them.

The social media companies will rue the day when they started favoring one point of view over another. But here's why that matters. Would Americans tolerate it if you paid differently for your electricity, your water or your telephone based on your political view of where you went to church? You would be outraged. Liberal conservative or independent, you'd be outraged. That's what we're seeing today.

BARTIROMO: And there's also so-called, shadowed banning, James, I mean --

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You know, I mean, I had put out a tweet about James Clapper basically admitting on CNN that President Obama directed the Intelligence Agencies to launch investigation for the special counsel on the Trump- Russia and I -- and I -- and basically Jim Clapper -- James Clapper admitted it on CNN. So I tweeted that out, it got no life, no -- and I thought, you know, this is something that I know my followers care about.

And I felt to myself, hmm, is that shadow banning? I don't know. I wonder if my followers saw that tweet or if it just went on deaf ears.

FREEMAN: Well, we've had a bunch of these teases where certainly conservative viewpoints seem to be suppressed. The answers from Silicon Valley generally are often not denials but sort of saying, well, it wasn't intentional, it's the algorithm.

BARTIROMO: But somebody programs the algorithm change.

FREEMAN: Yes. So, I agree. I think there's enough ear to say there is a problem of bias. It's -- I think it -- I'm hoping first there's a consumer remedy, we've seen user growth surprisingly kind of flattened --

BARTIROMO: You're right.

urn:contentItem:60DT-NN41-F07F-82KN-00000-00Tesla’s $200-billion question remains unanswered2020-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisNEWSTesla’s $200-billion question remains unanswered

By Chris Bryant You know Tesla Inc. is maturing as a carmaker when it manages to be slightly dull. Wednesday evening’s earnings update was even more eagerly anticipated than usual after the recent surge in its share price. Elon Musk’s company has added an ... By Chris Bryant You know Tesla Inc. is maturing as a...

By Chris Bryant You know Tesla Inc. is maturing as a carmaker when it manages to be slightly dull. Wednesday evening’s earnings update was even more eagerly anticipated than usual after the recent surge in its share price. Elon Musk’s company has added an ...

By Chris Bryant You know Tesla Inc. is maturing as a carmaker when it manages to be slightly dull. Wednesday evening’s earnings update was even more eagerly anticipated than usual after the recent surge in its share price. Elon Musk’s company has added an astonishing $200 billion to its already ample market capitalization since the end of March. Confirmation that Tesla will add a second U.S. factory, in Austin, Texas, is certainly something to celebrate — especially for the workers it will employ there to build its Cybertruck and other products. So too is a fourth consecutive quarter of net profit, which may prompt the company’s inclusion in the S&P500. And yet the earnings call — where Musk has in the past ranted about “fascist” virus lockdowns and attacked analysts for asking “boring, bonehead” questions — was a bit of a snooze. It even featured a long discussion about insurance and Musk’s appreciation for the actuarial profession. In the current economic environment, such steadiness is an achievement. Most car companies will probably suffer huge losses because of the recent closures of factories and showrooms, even if things won’t be quite as bad as feared initially. By contrast, Tesla reported $104 million of net income in the April to June period, bringing its total profit over the past four quarters to $368 million. Still, these are modest amounts for a company that’s valued at an inexplicable 800 times trailing earnings, giving it a $295 billion market capitalization. The profits are also more than accounted for by $1 billion of regulatory credits that Tesla sold to other carmakers during the 12 months to June, including $428 million in the latest quarter. It’s only able to earn this income because rivals haven’t gotten their act together yet on building enough electric vehicles and have to buy credits from Musk’s company to satisfy emissions regulators. Tesla acknowledges this good fortune won’t last forever. At a time when Musk is building three new factories on three continents, money from any source is welcome. Tesla says its $8.6 billion pile of cash and equivalents is sufficient to fund its expansion. But raising capital would barely dilute shareholders given how inflated the stock is. Investors might even welcome it. The second-quarter earnings won’t, however, settle the debate about whether demand for Tesla cars is starting to tail off in important markets. While Musk says this isn’t a problem, the company has been cutting prices in North America and China. His explanation is that the cheaper the cars are, the more people will buy them. So long as the company remains “slightly profitable” and avoids going “bankrupt” — in his words — then he sounds happy to sacrifice a bit of profit margin to drive growth. Tesla isn’t growing all that much right now, which is hard to square with the massive jump in its share price. Revenue declined 5% year on year in the latest quarter. The pandemic will have taken a toll, but Tesla will only really start to merit its “Big Tech” valuation once its top line starts firing again.

(Bloomberg Opinion) -- You know Tesla Inc. is maturing as a carmaker when it manages to be slightly dull. Wednesday evening’s earnings update was even more eagerly anticipated than usual after the recent surge in its share price. Elon Musk’s company has added an astonishing $200 billion to its already ample market capitalization since the end of March. Confirmation that Tesla will add a second U.S. factory in Austin, Texas is certainly something to celebrate — especially for the workers it will employ there to build its Cybertruck and other products. And yet the earnings call — where Musk has in the past ranted about “fascist” virus lockdowns and attacked analysts for asking “boring, bonehead” questions — was a bit of a snooze. It even featured a long discussion about insurance and Musk’s appreciation for the actuarial profession. In the current economic environment, such steadiness is an achievement. Most car companies will probably suffer huge losses because of the recent closures of factories and showrooms, even if things won’t be quite as bad as feared initially. By contrast, Tesla reported $104 million of net income in the April to June period, bringing its total profit over the past four quarters to $368 million. To be sure, these are modest amounts for a company with a $295 billion market capitalization and which is valued at an inexplicable 800 times trailing earnings. The profits are also more than accounted for by $1 billion of regulatory credits that Tesla sold to other carmakers during the 12 months to June, including $428 million in the latest quarter. It’s only able to earn this income because rivals haven’t gotten their act together yet on building enough electric vehicles and have to buy credits from Musk’s company to satisfy emissions regulators. Tesla acknowledges this good fortune won’t last forever. At a time when Musk is building three new factories on three continents, money from any source is welcome. Tesla says its $8.6 billion pile of cash and equivalents is sufficient to fund its expansion. But raising capital would barely dilute shareholders given how inflated the stock is. Investors might even welcome it. The second-quarter earnings won’t, however, settle the debate about whether demand for Tesla cars is starting to tail off in important markets. While Musk says this isn’t a problem, the company has been cutting prices in North America and China. His explanation is that the cheaper the cars are, the more people will buy them. So long as the company remains “slightly profitable” and avoids going “bankrupt” — in his words — then he sounds happy to sacrifice a bit of profit margin to drive growth. Tesla isn’t growing all that much right now, which is hard to square with the massive jump in its share price. Revenue declined 5% year on year in the latest quarter. The pandemic will have taken a toll, but Tesla will only really start to merit its “Big Tech” valuation once its top line starts firing again. urn:contentItem:60DR-JW71-JCDM-J01P-00000-00Tesla spends year terrifying, electrifying Wall Street2020-07-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisCPg. 4Tesla spends year terrifying, electrifying Wall StreetTOM KRISHER and MICHAEL LIEDTKE The Associated Press

BY TOM KRISHER

and MICHAEL LIEDTKE

The Associated Press

DETROIT - Tesla's losses were mounting last summer, massive debt payments were looming, and both Wall Street and federal regulators had run out of patience with the erratic behavior of CEO Elon Musk.

One year ago this week, shares plunged 14% after Tesla posted another quarterly loss, this one for $408 million, wiping out about $6 billion of the company's worth.

Since then, the stock has blasted off like at rocket at SpaceX, another Musk-led company. Tesla's market value today is three times that of Ford, General Motors and FiatChrysler, combined. A single share of Tesla now goes for $1,600, a seven-fold increase from a year ago, making it one of the most expensive publicly traded shares in the world.

"Things just turned on a dime," said CFRA Analyst Garrett Nelson. "It's just been one positive announcement after another."

In the past year, the electric car and solar panel maker successfully opened a factory in China, introduced the Model Y electric SUV, made debt payments, and it has posted profits for three straight quarters. Musk toned down the posts on Twitter that had cost him and the company $40 million in penalties from U.S. securities regulators.

A day before the company posts quarterly results one year removed from that week in 2019, industry analysts have begun to question if Tesla is running too hot. Analysts polled by FactSet expect a $228 million net loss from April through June. Only one analyst has a 12-month stock price target above the current value.

Tesla's stock surge has enriched Musk, boosting his net worth to an estimated $73.5 billion. He passed Warren Buffett, the Sage of Omaha, on the Forbes Billionaires list. And Musk could be headed for another big payday soon under his ambitious Tesla compensation package. In total, Musk and other Tesla shareholders have made about $240 billion since March 18, the low point for the stock price this year.

With second-quarter sales of Tesla vehicles outpacing the first despite a global pandemic, shares could jump again if Tesla surprises with its fourth consecutive profitable quarter. That would likely check all the boxes and could lead to Tesla's admission into the club of corporate giants: The S&P 500 stock index.

But it may be a Cinderella story.

CFRA's Nelson says shares have outpaced Tesla's fundamental performance, and he's telling clients to sell. He placed a price target at about two-thirds the current value of shares.

In an interview, Nelson said April-to-June registrations of Tesla vehicles fell by nearly half in California, the company's biggest market. That's an indication of waning demand for its vehicles, which start at $37,990 for a base Model 3 that can easily hit $60,000 with options.

Tesla also cut the price of its long-range Model Y by $3,000, which Nelson sees as a red flag. And the company is about to engage in a bout of heavy spending with new factories going up in Germany and the U.S.

There are also market factors that have flung share prices beyond what would be considered a rational trajectory, Nelson said.

Short sellers that perceived flaws at Tesla have since been buying shares to cover massive losses as the stock price leapt, Nelson said. Short-sellers now account for only 7.5% of Tesla's outstanding stock, down from over 23% a year ago, he said.

Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas has a $740 price target on Tesla, telling investors in a note that the market has given the company too much of a share of future electric vehicle and connected car revenue.

The valuation of Tesla shares has entered the orbit of Apple and Amazon, which took off after hitting $300 billion in market value like Tesla did last week, Jonas wrote. But Tesla's revenue and pretax earnings are far smaller than either tech company when they reached the $300 billion mark, he told investors.

Those who buy Tesla at around $1,500 per share have to believe that long-term U.S.-China trade relations will remain stable, older automakers will fail to make competitive electric vehicles, and big tech companies such as Google, Amazon and Apple won't be successful in developing electric vehicle systems, he wrote.

Jonas. who is uneasy about deteriorating relations between the world's two biggest economies, says traditional automakers are ready to spend over $400 billion on electric vehicles in the next five years, and he expects tech companies to enter the transportation business.

The dizzying run-up in Tesla's stock has positioned Musk for a lucrative payday just a few months after the Palo Alto, California, company awarded him a stock package worth more than $700 million.

That marked the first windfall in an incentive-laden deal that Tesla's board worked out two years ago to inspire Musk to build a company that eventually generates $175 billion in revenue, and is valued at $650 billion.

Tesla's market value during the past six months has averaged $149 billion, according to data compiled Monday by FactSet Research. That's just a $1 billion below the next hurdle that needs to be cleared for Musk to receive 1.69 million stock options valued at $350.02, or nearly 80% below Monday's closing price of $1,643.

The huge gap would make those stock options worth $2.2 billion on paper, although Musk wouldn't be able to sell the shares for five years.

Musk qualified for his first batch of 1.69 billion stock options in early May after Tesla's market value averaged $100 billion for a six-month period. The company also reached revenue and adjusted earnings goals needed for Musk to receive the first of 12 potential awards that could be worth tens of billions of dollars.

urn:contentItem:60DK-5VX1-JBVR-3344-00000-00Tesla's spent a year terrifying, electrifying Wall Street2020-07-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESSTesla's spent a year terrifying, electrifying Wall StreetTom Krisher And Michael LiedtkeThe Associated Press

DETROIT - Tesla's losses were mounting last summer, massive debt payments were looming, and both Wall Street and federal regulators had run out of patience with the erratic behaviour of CEO Elon Musk.

One year ago this week, shares plunged 14% after Tesla posted another quarterly loss, this one for $408 million, wiping out about $6 billion of the company's worth.

Since then the stock has blasted off like a rocket at SpaceX, another Musk-led company. The electric car and solar panel maker has successfully opened a factory in China, introduced the Model Y electric SUV, made debt payments and posted profits for three straight quarters. Musk has also toned down his inflammatory posts on Twitter that had cost him and the company $40 million in penalties from U.S. securities regulators.

Today, Tesla's market value is three times that of Ford, General Motors and FiatChrysler, combined. A single share of Tesla now goes for nearly $1,600 - a seven-fold increase from a year ago - making it one of the most expensive publicly traded shares in the world.

"Things just turned on a dime," said Garrett Nelson, an analyst at CFRA who specializes in the automotive industry. "It's just been one positive announcement after another."

The dizzying performance on Tuesday qualified Musk for his second huge payday in less than three months, this one worth more than $2 billion. His net worth has soared to an estimated $72 billion, just behind Warren Buffett on the Forbes Billionaires list after passing the famed investor earlier this month. In total, Musk and other Tesla shareholders have made about $240 billion since March 18 when the stock stood at $361 - its low point for this year.

With second-quarter sales of Tesla vehicles outpacing the first despite a global pandemic, shares could jump again if Tesla surprises on Wednesday with a fourth consecutive profitable quarter. That could lead to Tesla's admission into the club of corporate giants: the S&P 500 stock index.

But analysts have begun to question if the shares are running too hot. Analysts polled by FactSet expect a $228 million net loss from April through June. Only one analyst has a 12-month stock price target above the current value. A message was left Tuesday seeking comment from Tesla.

Nelson says shares have outpaced Tesla's fundamental performance, and he's telling clients to sell. He placed a price target at about two-thirds the current value of shares.

In an interview, Nelson said April-to-June registrations of Tesla vehicles fell by nearly half in California, the company's biggest U.S. market. That's an indication of waning demand for its vehicles, which start at $37,990 for a base Model 3 but the car can easily hit $60,000 with options.

Tesla also cut the price of its long-range Model Y by $3,000, which Nelson sees as a red flag. And the company is about to engage in a bout of heavy spending with new factories going up in Germany and the U.S.

There are also market factors that have flung share prices far higher, Nelson said.

Short sellers who perceived flaws at Tesla have since been buying shares to cover massive losses as the stock price leaped, Nelson said. Short-sellers now account for only 7.5% of Tesla's outstanding stock, down from over 23% a year ago, he said.

Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas has a $740 price target on Tesla, arguing that the market overestimates the company's share of future electric vehicle and connected car revenue.

Investors are treating Tesla like tech stocks Apple and Amazon, which took off years ago after hitting $300 billion in market value, Jonas wrote in an investor note. Tesla hit that mark last week, but its revenue and pretax earnings are far smaller than either tech company when they reached the $300 billion valuation, he wrote.

Those who buy Tesla at around $1,500 per share have to believe that long-term U.S.-China trade relations will remain stable, older automakers will fail to make competitive electric vehicles, and big tech companies such as Google, Amazon and Apple won't be successful in developing electric vehicle systems, he wrote.

Jonas, who is uneasy about deteriorating relations between the world's two biggest economies, says traditional automakers are ready to spend over $400 billion on electric vehicles in the next five years, and he expects tech companies to enter the transportation business.

In the meantime, Musk is sitting pretty. The run-up in Tesla's stock positioned him for a big payday after the Palo Alto, California, company awarded him a stock package worth more than $700 million in May.

That compensation is part of an incentive-laden deal that Tesla's board worked out two years ago to inspire Musk to build a company that eventually generates $175 billion in revenue, and is valued at $650 billion.

Musk cleared another hurdle Tuesday when Tesla's market value averaged $150 billion for a six-month stretch, according to data compiled by FactSet Research. Hitting that threshold means Musk is in line to receive 1.69 million stock options valued at $350.02, or nearly 80% below Tuesday's closing price of $1,568.36.

The huge gap would make those stock options worth $2.06 billion on paper, although Musk can't sell the shares for at least five years.

____

AP Business Writer Alex Veiga contributed from Los Angeles. Liedtke reported from San Ramon, California.

urn:contentItem:60DD-5WC1-JC5B-G4B2-00000-00Tesla's spent a year terrifying, electrifying Wall Street2020-07-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSTesla's spent a year terrifying, electrifying Wall StreetTOM KRISHER and MICHAEL LIEDTKEAP Business WritersDETROIT

DETROIT (AP) — Tesla's losses were mounting last summer, massive debt payments were looming, and both Wall Street and federal regulators had run out of patience with the erratic behavior of CEO Elon Musk.

One year ago this week, shares plunged 14% after Tesla posted another quarterly loss, this one for $408 million, wiping out about $6 billion of the company's worth.

Since then the stock has blasted off like a rocket at SpaceX, another Musk-led company. The electric car and solar panel maker has successfully opened a factory in China, introduced the Model Y electric SUV, made debt payments and posted profits for three straight quarters. Musk has also toned down his inflammatory posts on Twitter that had cost him and the company $40 million in penalties from U.S. securities regulators.

Today, Tesla's market value is three times that of Ford, General Motors and FiatChrysler, combined. A single share of Tesla now goes for nearly $1,600 — a seven-fold increase from a year ago — making it one of the most expensive publicly traded shares in the world.

“Things just turned on a dime,” said Garrett Nelson, an analyst at CFRA who specializes in the automotive industry. “It’s just been one positive announcement after another.”

The dizzying performance on Tuesday qualified Musk for his second huge payday in less than three months, this one worth more than $2 billion. His net worth has soared to an estimated $72 billion, just behind Warren Buffett on the Forbes Billionaires list after passing the famed investor earlier this month. In total, Musk and other Tesla shareholders have made about $240 billion since March 18 when the stock stood at $361 — its low point for this year.

With second-quarter sales of Tesla vehicles outpacing the first despite a global pandemic, shares could jump again if Tesla surprises on Wednesday with a fourth consecutive profitable quarter. That could lead to Tesla’s admission into the club of corporate giants: the S&P 500 stock index.

But analysts have begun to question if the shares are running too hot. Analysts polled by FactSet expect a $228 million net loss from April through June. Only one analyst has a 12-month stock price target above the current value. A message was left Tuesday seeking comment from Tesla.

Nelson says shares have outpaced Tesla's fundamental performance, and he's telling clients to sell. He placed a price target at about two-thirds the current value of shares.

In an interview, Nelson said April-to-June registrations of Tesla vehicles fell by nearly half in California, the company's biggest U.S. market. That's an indication of waning demand for its vehicles, which start at $37,990 for a base Model 3 but the car can easily hit $60,000 with options.

Tesla also cut the price of its long-range Model Y by $3,000, which Nelson sees as a red flag. And the company is about to engage in a bout of heavy spending with new factories going up in Germany and the U.S.

There are also market factors that have flung share prices far higher, Nelson said.

Short sellers who perceived flaws at Tesla have since been buying shares to cover massive losses as the stock price leaped, Nelson said. Short-sellers now account for only 7.5% of Tesla's outstanding stock, down from over 23% a year ago, he said.

Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas has a $740 price target on Tesla, arguing that the market overestimates the company's share of future electric vehicle and connected car revenue.

Investors are treating Tesla like tech stocks Apple and Amazon, which took off years ago after hitting $300 billion in market value, Jonas wrote in an investor note. Tesla hit that mark last week, but its revenue and pretax earnings are far smaller than either tech company when they reached the $300 billion valuation, he wrote.

Those who buy Tesla at around $1,500 per share have to believe that long-term U.S.-China trade relations will remain stable, older automakers will fail to make competitive electric vehicles, and big tech companies such as Google, Amazon and Apple won't be successful in developing electric vehicle systems, he wrote.

Jonas, who is uneasy about deteriorating relations between the world's two biggest economies, says traditional automakers are ready to spend over $400 billion on electric vehicles in the next five years, and he expects tech companies to enter the transportation business.

In the meantime, Musk is sitting pretty. The run-up in Tesla’s stock positioned him for a big payday after the Palo Alto, California, company awarded him a stock package worth more than $700 million in May.

That compensation is part of an incentive-laden deal that Tesla’s board worked out two years ago to inspire Musk to build a company that eventually generates $175 billion in revenue, and is valued at $650 billion.

Musk cleared another hurdle Tuesday when Tesla's market value averaged $150 billion for a six-month stretch, according to data compiled by FactSet Research. Hitting that threshold means Musk is in line to receive 1.69 million stock options valued at $350.02, or nearly 80% below Tuesday's closing price of $1,568.36.

The huge gap would make those stock options worth $2.06 billion on paper, although Musk can't sell the shares for at least five years.

____

AP Business Writer Alex Veiga contributed from Los Angeles. Liedtke reported from San Ramon, California.

urn:contentItem:60DH-S7H1-JCMN-Y27G-00000-00Tesla's spent a year terrifying, electrifying Wall Street2020-07-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisTesla's spent a year terrifying, electrifying Wall Street

Jul 21, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) In this March 9, 2020, file photo, Tesla and SpaceX Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk speaks at the SATELLITE Conference and Exhibition in Washington. Tesla has posted three straight profitable quarters, opened a factory in China and rolled out the Model Y small SUV. Yet ahead of second-quarter results on Wednesday, July 21, analysts are beginning to question whether the run will last. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)DETROIT (AP) — Tesla's losses were mounting last summer, massive debt payments were looming, and both Wall Street and federal regulators had run out of patience with the erratic behavior of CEO Elon Musk.

One year ago this week, shares plunged 14% after Tesla posted another quarterly loss, this one for $408 million, wiping out about $6 billion of the company's worth. Since then the stock has blasted off like at rocket at SpaceX, another Musk-led company. Tesla's market value today is three times that of Ford, General Motors and FiatChrysler, combined. A single share of Tesla now goes for $1,600, a seven-fold increase from a year ago, making it one of the most expensive publicly traded shares in the world. 'Things just turned on a dime,' said CFRA Analyst Garrett Nelson. 'It's just been one positive announcement after another.' In the past year, the electric car and solar panel maker successfully opened a factory in China, introduced the Model Y electric SUV, made debt payments and it's posted profits for three straight quarters. Musk toned down the posts on Twitter that had cost him and the company $40 million in penalties from U.S. securities regulators. A day before the company posts quarterly results one year removed from that week in 2019, industry analysts have begun to question if Tesla is running too hot. Analysts polled by FactSet expect a $228 million net loss from April through June. Only one analyst has a 12-month stock price target above the current value. Tesla's stock surge has enriched Musk, boosting his net worth to an estimated $73.5 billion. He passed Warren Buffett, the Sage of Omaha, on the Forbes Billionaires list. And Musk could be headed for another big payday soon under his ambitious Tesla compensation package. In total, Musk and other Tesla shareholders have made about $240 billion since March 18, the low point for the stock price this year. (Ad) Trump's 5G plan is opening the flood gates to 3 million new jobs, $12.3 trillion in economic growth, and a brand new 5G device. One of the world's top angel investors - a tech genius named Jeff Brown believes the company behind this device is the Number One Tech Stock of 202, and it will go from $0 to nearly $100 billion in sales - this year. With second-quarter sales of Tesla vehicles outpacing the first despite a global pandemic, shares could jump again if Tesla surprises with its fourth consecutive profitable quarter. That would likely check all the boxes and could lead to Tesla's admission into the club of corporate giants: The S&P 500 stock index. But it may be a Cinderella story. CFRA's Nelson says shares have outpaced Tesla's fundamental performance, and he's telling clients to sell. He placed a price target at about two-thirds the current value of shares. In an interview, Nelson said April-to-June registrations of Tesla vehicles fell by nearly half in California, the company's biggest market. That's an indication of waning demand for its vehicles, which start at $37,990 for a base Model 3 that can easily hit $60,000 with options. Tesla also cut the price of its long-range Model Y by $3,000, which Nelson sees as a red flag. And the company is about to engage in a bout of heavy spending with new factories going up in Germany and the U.S. There are also market factors that have flung share prices beyond what would be considered a rational trajectory, Nelson said. Short sellers that perceived flaws at Tesla have since been buying shares to cover massive losses as the stock price leapt, Nelson said. Short-sellers now account for only 7.5% of Tesla's outstanding stock, down from over 23% a year ago, he said. Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas has a $740 price target on Tesla, telling investors in a note that the market has given the company too much of a share of future electric vehicle and connected car revenue. The valuation of Tesla shares has entered the orbit of Apple and Amazon, which took off after hitting $300 billion in market value like Tesla did last week, Jonas wrote. But Tesla's revenue and pretax earnings are far smaller than either tech company when they reached the $300 billion mark, he told investors. Those who buy Tesla at around $1,500 per share have to believe that long-term U.S.-China trade relations will remain stable, older automakers will fail to make competitive electric vehicles, and big tech companies such as Google, Amazon and Apple won't be successful in developing electric vehicle systems, he wrote. Jonas. who is uneasy about deteriorating relations between the world's two biggest economies, says traditional automakers are ready to spend over $400 billion on electric vehicles in the next five years, and he expects tech companies to enter the transportation business. The dizzying run-up in Tesla's stock has positioned Musk for a lucrative payday just a few months after the Palo Alto, California, company awarded him a stock package worth more than $700 million. That marked the first windfall in an incentive-laden deal that Tesla's board worked out two years ago to inspire Musk to build a company that eventually generates $175 billion in revenue, and is valued at $650 billion. Tesla's market value during the past six months has averaged $149 billion, according to data compiled Monday by FactSet Research. That's just a $1 billion below the next hurdle that needs to be cleared for Musk to receive 1.69 million stock options valued at $350.02, or nearly 80% below Monday's closing price of $1,643. The huge gap would make those stock options worth $2.2 billion on paper, although Musk wouldn't be able to sell the shares for five years. Musk qualified for his first batch of 1.69 billion stock options in early May after Tesla's market value averaged $100 billion for a six-month period. The company also reached revenue and adjusted earnings goals needed for Musk to receive the first of 12 potential awards that could be worth tens of billions of dollars. ____ AP Business Writer Alex Veiga contributed from Los Angeles. Liedtke reported from San Ramon, California. Companies Mentioned in This Article The Next 5 Retailers on the Edge of Bankruptcy[1]Through no fault of theirs, the novel coronavirus has put some retailers on the edge of bankruptcy. And as you've seen, many have fallen over that edge including iconic names like Nieman Marcus, J.C. Penney and J.Crew. In fact, according to the American Bankruptcy Institute, there were 560 commercial Chapter 11 filings in April. That was a 26% increase over last year. And executive director, Amy Quakenboss, suggests that there are more to come. 'As financial challenges continue to escalate amid this crisis,' observes Quakenboss, 'bankruptcy is sure to offer a financial safe harbor from the economic storm.' With no revenue walking through the door, many retailers are seeing a semblance of revenue from e-commerce sales. But for some retailers, the shutdown is more impactful because they didn't have a strong e-commerce structure. That means that they rely more than others on brick-and-mortar sales. The real question now is will there really be the pent-up demand that some analysts still swear is just waiting to be unleashed. It may indeed exist. Time will tell. But time is not a commodity many of these retailers have. And we've identified five retailers for which the clock is not in their favor. View the "The Next 5 Retailers on the Edge of Bankruptcy"[2].
