Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VTB-KD81-JB20-G377-00000-00Tesla's Troubles; E-Cigarette Crackdown; College Admissions Scandal; Brexit Debate; President Donald Trump to Visit the Border Wall; Interview with Rep. Jeff Van Drew (D-NJ) about the Deadly Swine Flu Outbreak; House Judiciary Committee Voting 24-17 to Subpoena Robert Mueller Report; Patagonia Won't Sell Vests to Wall Street Firms; High Hopes for a Buyer's Market for Housing Market2019-04-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTJeff Van Drew, Dolly Lenz, Jenny Lenz, Erin Elmore, Tasha KeeneyNEWSFinancial040402cb.231Tesla's Troubles; E-Cigarette Crackdown; College Admissions Scandal; Brexit Debate; President Donald Trump to Visit the Border Wall; Interview with Rep. Jeff Van Drew (D-NJ) about the Deadly Swine Flu Outbreak; House Judiciary Committee Voting 24-17 to Subpoena Robert Mueller Report; Patagonia Won't Sell Vests to Wall Street Firms; High Hopes for a Buyer's Market for Housing MarketMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Griff Jenkins, James Freeman, Ashley Webster

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, April 4th.

Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Investors are waiting on any China trade news. The President will meet with China's top negotiator today at the White House.

Markets are flat, S&P 500 down a fraction, Dow Jones Industrial average up a fraction. This after markets were little changed yesterday. The Nasdaq was the top performer on the day yesterday. It was up two-thirds of 1 percent, 46 points higher. The other major indices higher but just fractionally. Dow Industrials up about 39 points yesterday.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the story and it is mixed. FT 100 down 30 points. CAC 40 in Paris down 9 points. But the DAX index in Germany up 26.

In Asia overnight markets were mostly higher as you can see here with the exception of Hong Kong.

We are waiting on the jobs report. It's jobs Friday tomorrow, that may very well be a market mover.

Cracking down on e-cigarettes. The FDA is warning of serious health concerns after some users are reporting they're getting seizures after vaping.

The college admissions scandal continues. Lori Loughlin and Felicity Huffman appearing in a Boston court yesterday, after they signed autographs outside. We have the very latest.

Plus the vests take over Wall Street. But now the company behind them, Patagonia, is saying no more. Wait until you hear that story.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman; and Republican strategist Erin Elmore.

Great to see you this morning.

Jamie Dimon has his annual letter out. The CEO of JPMorgan Chase out with his annual letter. And he writes this, "There are legitimate concerns around China's economy in addition to trade but they are manageable." He also calls the U.S. trade issues with China substantial and real.

The letter has become something that Jamie Dimon is real proud of, you know, as he takes a whack at policy issues and talks about concerns for the country, not just JPMorgan.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Yes. I think China obviously the big issue on the table. I think he's speaking for the business community, where they don't like tariffs but they recognize that the game in China is not fair to foreign companies. It's not fair on intellectual property, et cetera.

Larger policy points in there, I think some of them are laudable. But I don't like the idea that businesses have a sort of a social responsibility to advocate for different public policies. I think the job of a bank, for example, and his bank does it very well, is to fund businesses, allow companies to grow, allow people to have the financial services and I think that's a great service. You don't need to be involved in public policy.

BARTIROMO: You're right.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: This reads like a 10-point plan for a man who is running for the nomination of some party. I don't know which party it is.

But he talks about infrastructure spending and the infrastructure plan to improve our highways and such. That is the role of the government, how to pay for it is the question. Also things like --

BARTIROMO: Education.

MCDOWELL: -- education. Those are the big l policy issues. I mean, he's kind of -- again, tell us something we don't know.

BARTIROMO: He says ten ways to address what's holding back growth and opportunity, education, healthcare costs, regulatory reform, infrastructure, tax system, litigation reform, immigration reform, mortgage reform, labor market, budgeting and planning.

ERIN ELMORE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Jamie Dimon, 2020.

BARTIROMO: Yes. No, he said he's not going to run.

ELMORE: No, no. Definitely not.

MCDOWELL: He's not woke enough, I don't think, to certainly win the Democratic nomination and you already got like a Howard Schultz possibly running as an independent candidate. I wasn't suggesting that. I'm just saying it reads like a policy platform.

BARTIROMO: It does. You're absolutely right. But I will say this, he's probably going to be getting some good news recently -- good news in the near term on China because the Chinese are agreeing to open up their markets, particularly to financial services.

UBS was the first bank to get an opportunity to own a bank out and out, 51 percent. But it looks like financial services are going to be the first industry that really gets a shot to sell to the 1.4 billion people in China, which is a big opportunity.

FREEMAN: Yes. And if you look at what the Chinese have said recently, it sounds like reform. Obviously, there's this question, and this is sort of the sticking point in the trade negotiations right now, what is the enforcement mechanism? When do you take the tariffs off? How do you punish if they're not following the deal.

I think on the U.S. side, they are convinced that Liu He is a genuine reformer. He wants to move the Chinese economy toward open markets, the rule of law, respect for property. Can he sell that to Xi Jinping who is really an old-fashioned communist. And we'll hear from Gordon Chang who obviously covers this extremely well but covers this extremely well. But that's really the he question, I think is can He sell that reform opportunity back home.

BARTIROMO: And I'm expecting that meeting between the President and Xi Jinping in May, early May, is the guidance that I'm getting in terms of the meeting in Mar-a-Lago -- that must mean reform that they are really down to the final items as we told you yesterday actually.

Coming up this morning, we've got a great show.

Florida Congressman and House Judiciary Committee member Matt Gaetz is here. He'll be on the panel with New Jersey Congressman and House agriculture committee member Jeff Van Drew. We'll get both of their ideas.

Plus the author of "The Coming Collapse Of China", Gordon Chang is with us to talk about where we are in that deal. And former McDonald's CEO, and Fat Brands international chairman Ed Rensi joining is us as well. Don't miss a moment of it.

Now to the Securities and Exchange Commission versus Elon Musk, the Tesla chief headed to court today over his controversial tweets that have triggered a legal t battle between his company and the SEC. A federal judge will hear arguments in a lawsuit filed by the agency which is the court to hold Musk in contempt for violating a $40 million settlement.

Joining us now is ARK investment analyst Tasha Keeney. Tasha Keeney. Tasha it's god to see you.

TASHA KEENEY, ARK INVESTMENT ANALYST: Thanks for having me.

Have you been trading or recommending this stock in light of all this -- Tesla?

KEENEY: In light of the SEC Investigation?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Keeney: Well, we know -- we don't try to predict legal outcomes. We certainly don't know. But you know, Dagen I heard you say earlier, you don't think that he'll be removed as CEO. That's really most important to us. We want him to stay at the helm of the company. Especially if Tesla is still reaching for autonomy with its vehicles which what we think the largest market opportunity ahead of it.

MCDOWELL: Think about the outrage about that, if a federal judge because of a tweet -- a tweet violates a settlement with a securities regulator which has no really criminal authority over companies, it has -- it can file civil cases, having a judge remove a CEO for a tweet ain't going to happen.

BARTIROMO: Well, they want to remove President Trump for his lies; for his tweets.

ELMORE: And Tasha How do you manage your expectations given the fact that Elon Musk has such volatility in his behavior?

KEENEY: You know, we look at Musk really as a visionary. He's accomplished the impossible. I mean he's changing the face of the auto industry. So there's a lot of transparency in what he does because he uses Twitter.

And he has made mistakes in the past and he's admitted those and paid for those mistakes.

You know, I think, again, for the long term goal of the company in terms of getting to full autonomy, being a leader in electric vehicles, he seems to have a accomplished that. We're happy so far with how things are going.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But the company's new vehicle deliveries plummeted 31 percent in the first quarter. Tesla is citing challenges associated with taking the Model 3 overseas for the first time. How are they going to deal with this?

KEENEY: You know, it think there's too much focus on deliveries. Again, with an innovative company like this you have to look at the long-term picture. So if Tesla's late by say a month or what have you on those numbers -- I mean, are they -- it's still the best selling mid-size premium sedan. I mean there's no demand issue.

MCDOWELL: but again but it doers reflect and the "Wall Street Journal" writes about this in its analysis today.

"Tesla has trouble planning. And if you're going to be in the manufacturing business, you really need to learn how to cross your t's and dot your i's so-to-speak. Because Tesla produced 22 percent more cars than it was able to deliver in the first quarter. This shows in part a logistics problem. Now --

BARTIROMO: Is it going to hurt income --

MCDOWELL: It's more likely but Elon Musk kind -- and Tasha can attack about this. Elon Musk kind of forecast several weeks ago -- we were talking, remember about the debt payment. It was really about him saying that the company might not be profitable in the first quarter after two straight quarters of producing a profit because of some of the issues.

And in part, they are losing that tax credit as well. It was at $7,500. Now it's essentially been cut in half.

BARTIROMO: Stock is down 8 percent right now.

KEENEY: Yes. Exactly. So I think -- well, so one, in terms of profitability, I think so Tesla said they have enough cash on-hand at the end of the quarter and I think in general with the delivery figures, I mean, have you to ask yourself, are these logistic challenges going to kill the company? No. You know.

If you're a long-term investor, I don't think this should phase you.

FREEMAN: Wanted to ask about the tweets. Obviously this is a mechanism to speak to the markets and the company has said that, but people just like with the president, they argue are the tweets critical to his success or is he hurting himself with tweets.

I wonder how you view the Musk communications generally, whether it's Twitter, whether it's going on pod casts and smoking weed -- is this part of the brand and part of the genius or is it a downside and you wish he would stop talking?

KEENEY: You know, again, as I said earlier, with Twitter we get a lot of transparency. And you don't get that with other CEOs. So I think in a lot of ways investors, this gives us more information. Now, sometimes he does unpredictable things like the 420 but in general, you know, 420 tweet.

In general, again, we see the board supporting Musk which is really important for an innovative company like Tesla. And, you know, as we look forward as the auto industry transitions to electric autonomous vehicles, Tesla's years ahead of the competition.

And so we don't think that little blips like this are going to sort of affect that competitive advantage that Tesla's built in terms of batteries, in terms of autonomous hardware and in terms of autonomous data.

MCDOWELL: And you don't even need to look ahead to autonomous vehicles. I had this discussion with someone I'm very close to over the weekend who works in Silicon Valley. Every other automaker, even luxury automakers in Germany, Japanese and American -- they are awful at software.

There is no other car and no other car company that compares to a Tesla. We all as drivers and consumers ought to be rooting for this company. You don't have to own stock in it but you ought to be rooting for them because hopefully all these other automakers will realize oh, our software stinks.

KEENEY: Exactly. And automakers really haven't even owned that part of the supply chain. The software side of things. They're bringing in all of these components from different suppliers and Tesla's vertically integrated.

So this is a huge challenge to the traditional companies. And I mean if you don't -- just take one thing over the air updates. the car gets better overnight. Why haven't other automakers been able to do this? I mean it's ridiculous that Tesla's actually been doing this for years now. And no one has caught up.

MCDOWELL: Because they're dug in and they literally don't know now to run a car company in the new century. That's literally what these companies look like.

If you -- I'm surprised. And I'm surprised that Apple and Google haven't done more to try and manufacture a car or produce software for one.

FREEMAN: How secured is Tesla's funding?

Keeney: So, you know, I think in general if we look at funding for Tesla, ok, so say if you were worried about cash, we actually as investors would be ok with an equity dilution because we just want them to get as many cars on the road as possible. Each of the cars acts like a mini R&D center. It collects data for Tesla and it gets it toward that vision of full autonomy because Machine learning improves with the more data you feed it.

So we're actually factoring in a $10 billion to $20 billion equity dilution over the next five years. And again, we would be ok with that.

FREEMAN: How soon do they need to raise more capital?

KEENEY: So you know they've again, they said that they're ok with cash at the end of the quarter. So no immediate expectations for that to happen. Now, if things were to change which we certainly think they could, again, that would be ok.

BARTIROMO: Just to be clear, the stock is down almost 9 percent right now. Would you buy it here?

KEENEY: You know, I can't say whether or not we would buy or sell but you know, again, our long term visit .

BARTIROMO: You have to tell clients something, right?

KEENEY: Well, you know, the market hasn't opened yet. But the long-term vision for Tesla has not changed.

I mean we still think they're the largest producer of batteries in the world. They're the only company that's collecting data off its customer cars on the road, we've seen every other company that's working on autonomous driving have issues, Waymo is having technical issues, the commercial launch was much watered down than what se expected.

I mean Tesla could launch a fully autonomous car in the next couple of years and then they're really going to run away from the competition.

MCDOWELL: I still think he's acted like a jerk in the past but again, like I said everybody in this country ought to be rooting for the success of this company in one way shape or form because it is 's the way of the future.

BARTIROMO: Tasha -- thanks for being here.

KEENEY: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Tasha Keeney, ARK Investment.

Coming up a major e-cigarettes warning this morning, dozens of users reporting to the FDA that they're suffering features. The health risk around vaping coming up.

And then changing the Wall Street" uniform. Patagonia takes a stand when it comes to which companies wear its clothes. Stay with us. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

A new potential health risk for e-cigarette users. Cheryl Casone with headlines now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Pretty serious one, Maria.

The Food and Drug administration is revealing about three dozen reports of seizures among e-cigarette users, mainly younger people. Nicotine poisoning is believed to cause seizures and even brain injury. Last month the FDA outlined new restrictions on sales of most flavored e-cigs to fight underage use of them.

Well, billionaire/investor, Carl Icahn reportedly sold his stake in Lyft to fellow billionaire, George Soros before the company's IPO last week. Sources telling the "Wall Street Journal" that Icahn held about a 2.7 percent stake in Lyft which was valued at about $550 million -- that's the IPO price.

It is not known why Icahn sold his stake or how much Soros paid for it. Lyft is up about a fraction of a percent this morning.

Three global automakers teaming up to create safety standards for self- driving cars. Ford, GM and Toyota plan to set up the automated vehicle safety consortium, focusing on building a safety framework for autonomous vehicles. Self-driving cars have come under increased scrutiny since, of course, the fatal crash of an Uber test vehicle last year. The Ford, GM, Toyota initiative is notable because it involves large car makers but no technology firms who probably will want to weigh in on any new rules.

And those are your headlines -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: all right. Cheryl -- thank you.

Coming up, the delay in the U.K., trying to avoid a no deal exit from the European Union. British lawmakers are now looking for another deadline extension. We've got the details out of London coming up. then the college admissions scandal, Lori Loughlin and Felicity Huffman facing a judge. The courtroom drama coming up.

BARTIROMO: British lawmakers are voting to force prime minister Theresa May to ask the E.U. for another extension to exit the European Union.

Ashley Webster with the very latest right now.

WEBSTER: We go around and around and --

BARTIROMO: Round and round and round.

WEBSTER: -- and around we go. Nothing much as changes other than yes there is a bill that whisked it went through the House of commons yesterday, basically telling Theresa May that she must go to The European Union and ask for an extension which, by the way, the new deadline is a week from tomorrow.

That went through the House of commons. It's now in the House of Lords. It's kind of like the House and the Senate in the U.K.

Generally nothing of interest ever happens in the House of Lords so this is ground-breaking by itself, that they're actually debating this issue in the House of Lords and doing it quickly. Nothing quickly happens in the House of Lords.

And now there's a belief that some conservatives in the House of Lords are so upset with this whole process they may filibuster. They may talk for hours and hours and hours and hours and hours to try to prevent this from going through.

The bottom line ok, Prime Minister go ask for another deadline from the E.U. It doesn't mean the E.U. is going to give it to them. for the an tension, doesn't mean the E.U. is going to give it to them.

What's interesting is this whole affair has not really moved forward in three years. You can't come to a majority, a consensus on what the plan is to get the heck out of the E.U.

What's interesting though is there's a new poll out in the U.K., that says 83 percent of U.K. citizens, sick of talking about Brexit, 64 percent believe it's harmful to their mental health.

I think we can all agree with that. But it's certainly --

And another interesting angle to this, Maria and gang, there are 10,000 riot police that have been undergoing extensive training in the last couple of weeks. They are ready to deploy in a heartbeat. That doesn't mean to say they're going to be needed but there has been a ramping up of emotions

The number of crimes related to Brexit have doubled in the last two weeks. Not a huge amount but there are incidents where harsh rhetoric is now being translated into actual action. And there's actual a concern if this continues to drag on and Brexit is not delivered as it was requested by the British people in that referendum, that things could spill on the streets.

There are 10,000 riot troops ready to go. It's a little . And there's a concern if this continues to drag on and the Brexit is not delivered as it was requested by the British riot troops ready to go.

It's a little bit of a scare thing. Haven't been used and so far, it's been pretty civil, I have to say. But there's no doubt tensions and emotions are frayed.

MCDOWELL: There are always people looking for a reason to loot, aren't they?

WEBSTER: Certainly in France. There's always a small group of anarchists who will jump onto any cause just so they can smash up some shops.

MCDOWELL: And get what?

WEBSTER: Get some free jeans. Get free stuff. There's always that.

MCDOWELL: That's Ashley's -- East London accent.

WEBSTER: Yes. But there are people who would jump on any cause just to create problems. So there is that kind of lurking in the background.

Bottom line is can Theresa May survive this? Who knows? Who would want her job right now.

FREEMAN: But if she cuts a deal with the Labour Party --

WEBSTER: Jeremy Corbyn.

FREEMAN: this is going to be either no Brexit or something that's VERY close to no Brexit.

WEBSTER: Correct. It's going to be a very soft Brexit. And you know, will Corbyn insist on a second referendum, no matter what deal they make, the choice going back to the people, saying this is the deal we've got.

Vote for this or we forget the whole thing and stay in Europe. That could be the next move.

BARTIROMO: What will that do to markets.

WEBSTER: Uncertainties, sterling ha taken another hit. We know that it's funny, you know the economic news out of Europe, German manufacturing again came out really poor.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And Italy and Germany GDP were cut.

WEBSTER: This is not a good time economically for the E.U. and certainly the U.K. slowed down. None of this is good because of the uncertainty. Businesses aren't spending. Businesses don't know what to do, especially if you have a lot of exposure to the continent.

FREEMAN: This referendum the people voted for -- they voted for Brexit --

WEBSTER: 52 to 48 percent.

FREEMAN: -- is basically being ignored on the installment plan, by the politicians.

WEBSTER: Correct. It was always 70 something percent of MPs who voted to remain and there's this strong belief that they would do anything they can to prevent it from happening. And one way to do that is to drag it out, get the U.K. involved in the European parliament elections coming up in May. They do that this thing gets pushed further and further and further down the line. And that happens is no Brexit. That is the fear.

BARTIROMO: And it's all having an impact across the world. I'm glad you mentioned the factory orders report out of Germany because you're the Eurozone economic numbers do not look good.

WEBSTER: There you go.

BARTIROMO: This morning the GDP expectations for Italy and Germany were cut again. They're lucky to get 1 percent growth if at all in the Eurozone.

WEBSTER: Right. Completely stagnant.

BARTIROMO: That has to hit the U.S. at some point.

WEBSTER: Of course it does. And you know, no matter what you think of the E.U. it's a huge trading bloc. It is enormous and there's a lot of business done between the U.S. and the E.U. So it is going to have an impact.

MCDOWELL: I was going to say, meantime you have political candidates here in the United States pointing to Europe as kind of the gold standard. Yes, their economy can't grow.

WEBSTER: Good point.

MCDOWELL: This is what socialism gets you.

FREEMAN: This could be an upside for us. I was talking to one European BANK and he was saying this all of this debate and concern and uncertainty helps New York remain the world's financial center.

WEBSTER: It does. It's the only game in town. And where are you going to put your money right now? U.S. equities look pretty good.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point. Are American businesses, JPMorgans of the world, have they made a plan to stay in the U.K. or move some of their people to Germany? What's the story.

WEBSTER: There have been a lot of movement. Bank of America moved a lot of its employees out of the -- out of London and to Dublin, to Ireland because their because they'll remain in the E.U.

FREEMAN: I THINK There's no obvious competitor in Europe, Dublin, Frankfurt maybe has an argument, but I think London remains the European financial center because of the tradition, rule of law, people want to operate there.

WEBSTER: Certainly hope so.

FREEMAN: I think that's probably true regardless of what the is.

WEBSTER: Yes. I think you're right.

BARTIROMO: Ashley -- great stuff. Thank you so much.

WEBSTER: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Ashley Webster with the latest there.

Coming up, the border battle, we're taking you live to the border next.

Plus, I'll be talking with two lawmakers about the economic impact, if the President closes the U.S.-Mexico border.

And then millennials in the housing market. They are resurrecting the suburbs but refusing sprawling homes. Real estate trends up next.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, April 4th. Your top stories right now, 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Futures are indicating fractional moves at the start of trading this morning. Dow Industrials are up seven points, the S&P is down under one point and the NASDAQ down 7-1/2.

The major indices inching higher yesterday on hopes for a U.S.-China trade deal. The S&P 500 and the NASDAQ both hit 2019 highs yesterday, up six points on the S&P, NASDAQ up 46. Dow Industrials were up 39 points.

The 10-year treasury yield settling above 2-1/2 percent for the first time in two weeks. Remember, we were look at that yield down to 2.36 percent earlier in the week and last week. This morning, settling at 2-1/2.

In Europe this morning, the major indices are quiet. As you see, the FT- 100 down 31 points, the CAC Quarante is down 13, the DAX Index is up 20, we just heard that we had some disappointing factory orders data out of Germany and this morning the GDP forecasts have been cut in Italy and in Germany.

In Asia overnight, markets finished like this. Mostly higher with the exception of Hong Kong, the Shanghai Composite the best performer, up almost one percent in China.

Well, the college admission scandal, actresses Lori Loughlin and Felicity Huffman appear before a judge. The courtroom drama coming up.

Home buying heats up again. We are taking a look at millennials in the housing market, it is shaping up to be the best in years.

And Wall Street's wardrobe shake up, get this, outdoor clothing retailer Patagonia is cracking down on its iconic corporate logo vests, a staple across big tech and financial firms. Why the company is now saying no to some industry giants.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. But first, our top story this half an hour, the border battle, President Trump will visit the southern border in California tomorrow. Griff Jenkins is at the border in McAllen, Texas right now. Griff, good morning.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. We just got some numbers here in the Rio Grande Valley. I'm just steps from the border here. That there were over 1,100 apprehensions of illegal crossers last night. That is the 13th day of more than a thousand apprehensions that they're having in this surge of migrants, many of them family units. We encountered more than 180 when we spent all day with the border patrol out on watch. But they don't all surrender peacefully seeking asylum, sometimes they seek to evade being caught. And we went into the sticks with them. It's tough work. Here's what happened.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: It's unbelievably difficult terrain. I'm cut, my gloves torn. This man rushing through here and we found a group, this is the first one we found, just nothing but thorns, bushes, bugs, snakes, spiders.

This is a spotlight. You can see (INAUDIBLE), there they are. They've got two more.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE) they tried to run. This one right here was hiding underneath this brush to my left and this one right here just got up from the brush and took off running south but I was able to get him before he went got away.

JENKINS: This is the brush underneath here, right where I am, where the last illegal crosser was laid down and Herman had to crawl in like this and go through these bushes and thorns. It's just treacherous.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: And that is not an extraordinary night by any stretch. That's what they go through every night here. Also folks are worried about this border closing.

As you know, Maria, Mexico is Texas' biggest trade partner to the tune of $187 billion. We wait to see what happens as DHS Secretary Nielsen visits Arizona today, the president to California tomorrow.

BARTIROMO: Wow, it really looks like a crisis there, Griff. Thank you. Griff Jenkins joining us in McAllen this morning.

President Trump is threatening to close the southern border all together. Mexican officials along the border are warning a port of entry delays are already causing tens of millions of dollars in losses for companies that do business along the border. White House Economic director Larry Kudlow said that there's a way to keep freight lanes open should the border close.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR, WHITE HOUSE: But regarding the economic impact of closing the border, which has not -- the president has not made a decision yet, as you know, I'm not aware that he has, one area we've explored is to try to keep the freight lanes open. The truck lanes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is congressman and House Agricultural Committee member, Jeff Van Drew. Congressman, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thank you so much for being here.

REP. JEFF VAN DREW (D-NJ), HOUSE AGRICULTURAL COMMITTEE MEMBER: Thanks, and it's always a pleasure to be here with you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So, your reaction to this news this morning. We're seeing the lines get longer. We're seeing a lot of worry over the threat that the president could close the border. How do you see it?

VAN DREW: I sure -- I certainly hope he doesn't have to close the border. I wouldn't want to see that. It's obviously not good for business, it's not good for the economy. So I'm hopeful that we can work this out.

Yet another example, and I know I drive it over and over again, but where we just need to have -- you know, more conversation, more bipartisanship. We really need to do more here at the border to try to straighten this out. If we can get the border under control, then we won't have the problem at the ports of entry with moving things through quickly enough. And that's the issue.

BARTIROMO: You know, congressman, this is one of those examples of there are real issues happening in the country and in the world and instead, we have been focused in the last two years on this collusion narrative. I know that you have come to Washington to get things done. How are you dealing with your colleagues that seem to only want to take down Donald Trump and have ignored all of the issues going on that affect the American people?

VAN DREW: Well, I had a serious conversation with some of them just last night where we sat around a table and talked about it and I agree with exactly what you're saying. I want to get things done. People don't even realize at this point the bills that you hear about moving through the House of Representatives. Most of them, the vast majority of them are not going anywhere. They're going to get stopped at the senate, because, again, we're not having that conversation. They're not moving through and becoming law.

So, I think at so many levels we need to take care of the issues that are real, whether it's Social Security, Medicare, healthcare, making sure that our veterans are taken care of. I can go through an entire list for about 10 minutes of things that we need to do. We need to get past this other part.

So, we're going to get the report. Let's get the report, get as much that -- of it that is legal, and I want to emphasize that, that we legally can get, take a look at it. If there's something there, deal with it. If there's nothing there, that is horrendous, let's move on. Let's get laws passed that -- you know, really can make a difference. Let's get our business sector going even better. Let's take care of the border issues so that we don't have what's now -- was first just a crisis of safety, is now also a humanitarian crisis and a business crisis.

BARTIROMO: Yes for sure. Then there's China and this of course impacts your constituents being on the Agricultural Committee. I want to ask you about what's going on in China because I heard a story last night which really concerned me. There is a swine flu outbreak in China, this deadly virus said to be spreading throughout the country, affecting a shocking number of pigs. China consumes and produces 50 percent of the world's pork. But apparently 20 percent of the pigs are sick from this swine flu and they've got a hundred million pigs to dispose of. Dead pigs.

In the past they would put the pigs in the -- in the ocean and just leave it. But there are literally a hundred million dead pigs in China. Have you heard about this? Do you think there's going to be an impact to our agriculture? Some people expect that this situation is going to ripple through different meats, chicken and steak, in terms of prices. It's going to push all prices higher. What do you think?

VAN DREW: Well, it's definitely going to push some prices higher, there's no question. When -- you're going to have a shortage of meat and you're going to certainly going to have a shortage of pork and the prices are going to go up, number one.

Secondly, you know, we just have to make sure and thank God we have got a good Department of AGs to make sure that we keep everything safe over here. Just to -- you know, arrest everybody's fears, this is nothing that you or I can catch from eating something. This is something that goes from animal to animal through a variety of ways, sometimes when they eat waste that is infected from the flies and the transient insects that move around. But it's a serious issue. It's another serious issue. It's another economic issue. These are the types of issues that government should be working on.

BARTIROMO: What are you expecting out of a China deal? The president is expected to tell us later today when he will meet President Xi in Mar-a- Lago. I'm thinking -- I'm hearing it's either end of April, but likely -- more likely the beginning of May. Do you think the U.S. is going to be able to get an enforcement mechanism in there to ensure that the Chinese do not steal intellectual property from America?

VAN DREW: It may not be as good as we would want, but it's got to be better than it is. Because it's something we can't put up with anymore. And the stealing of intellectual property, the tampering with their monetary system as you know and many of the other things that they do are things that we just can't tolerate. I think there's truth to those who say that for too long China has had the better end of the deal and I think we have to protect our American interest.

So I think this, again, is another very, very important issue that we've got to work on. I think we're going to do better. I believe we're going to do better. But you know, Maria, this is going to be some hard, tough negotiating that's going to take place. We're not playing with amateurs here. These folks are serious. And they're serious about being the new number one in the world.

BARTIROMO: That's right. And they're looking long term but I think during the whole -- you know, Mueller report drama, the Chinese were questioning if they're even going to have to deal with Donald Trump. Now after we know officially no collusion, the Chinese are saying we might have to deal with this guy for another eight years. It just also underlines how irresponsible there was -- it was out there, the media, the Democrats, you know, parading around with this collusion story, basically giving an upper hand to the Chinese while he's trying to do a deal with them.

You mentioned the Mueller report a moment ago. It's going to come out. The Judiciary Committee voted 24-17 to subpoena the entire report. Some members of the special counsel team reportedly saying that the results are more damaging to President Trump than Attorney General William Barr led on, that's coming from the New York Times today, the New York Times is clinging to this narrative, obviously. Would the A.G. hide something? I mean, would the new A.G. hide something in the Mueller report?

VAN DREW: Well, call me naive, but I really believe in the system of law. And I believe he wants to ensure to keep his good name, so I believe he's going to release what is supposed to be released. (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Not the grand jury testimony, right, though?

VAN DREW: Correct. He can't release that. That's by law. But those areas where we're not going to hurt people, not the grand jury testimony, not something obviously that's confidential for certain reasons but the majority of it, a good piece of that report could be released.

And if that's true, then that will come out. I'm one -- let me say this, you know, I'm a Democrat. But frankly, I was glad when it seems to be that there might not be much there because it's important that we can move forward for the next year and-a-half that our president can be effective. We're going to have an election, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Right.

VAN DREW: When we have that election, we can hash --

BARTIROMO: Let the voters decide.

VAN DREW: Exactly. Let the voters decide. Let's hash this out. Let's have the big, grand argument that everybody wants to have.

BARTIROMO: Right.

VAN DREW: Right now is the time to accomplish goals and get things done. And the China deal is an example.

BARTIROMO: Well, one thing that the voters are going to decide on -- one thing that the voters are going to decide on are some of these radical ideas, congressman. I mean, Senator Elizabeth Warren introduced a bill for CEOs to receive jail time after data breaches. Warren treated this yesterday, today I'm proposing a new law that expands criminal liability to any corporate executive who negligently oversees a company that causes severe and widespread harm to families. Our justice system should ensure that if you cheat working Americans, you'll go to jail. She wants to make it easier for CEOs to go to jail, congressman. What do you think?

VAN DREW: Well, I think if they've done something truly wrong, truly hurtful and truly illegal, then there can be some truth to that.

BARTIROMO: Right.

VAN DREW: But I don't necessarily love a full-fledged attack that's occurring in certain sectors on business in general. That business is bad, that the capitalistic system is bad, that we should change the whole playing field. You know, I've said this to you before I'm a capitalist. I'm proud to be a capitalist. I'm a capitalist and I like to -- you know, have a little phone that I'm a compassionate capitalist. But that -- I mean that for real that -- you know, there is a place for government. We want to make sure people don't fall through the cracks. This is not just Laissez-faire capitalism.

However, we want to make sure that this economic engine that is taking so many of us to such good places in so many ways is even expanded more and even takes more of us and enables us to live the American dream.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well-said, congressman. Good to see you, sir. Thanks so much.

VAN DREW: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Jeff Van Drew.

Coming up, the college admissions scandal is next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Constellation Brands out with earnings right now. Cheryl Casone with the details, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We've got the numbers, Maria. Constellation Brands reporting better than expected results for Q4. The company posting adjusted profit of a $1.84 a share, revenue of $1.8 billion. The company also selling about 30 of its lower priced wine brands to E. & J. Gallo for $1.7 billion. Some of the names, Clos du Bois, Mark West wines and several others. Shares of Constellation Brands higher in the premarket.

All right. Well, actresses Felicity Huffman and Lori Loughlin appearing for the first time in federal court in Boston over the college admissions scandal. Both are charged with conspiracy to commit fraud. Prosecutors reportedly asking for jail time for everyone charged in the case. Now the actresses have forfeited their passports. Loughlin, we should ask, stopped to sign autographs outside of the courthouse after her appearance, Aunt Becky fans in Boston yesterday.

All right, Patagonia no longer selling its popular vest through corporate sales programs. These vests with finance from logos on them , kind of a wardrobe staple on Wall Street if you're a New Yorker, especially for those workers that trade in those formal suits for that more casual look for the trading floor. Patagonia says it wants to add new businesses to its client list, ones that quote, meet certain environmental, social and transparency standards. The company adding existing corporate customers can remain in the program. OK, way to make your views there.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

CASONE: Patagonia.

BARTIROMO: That's too much.

CASONE: I know.

BARTIROMO: All right, thank you, Cheryl.

Coming up, real estate is heating up. Investors are finding it's the perfect time to make a buck in the housing market. Details on the making - - the money making opportunity rather. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: President Trump just tweeted on the GOP. Here's what the president writes, the Republican Party is the party of the American dream.

Well, let's talk about that because spring has sprung for potential home buyers, falling rates and increased inventory pushing a buyer's market. Joining us now to give us the state of business is Dolly Lenz Real Estate co-founder, Dolly Lenz and Dolly Lenz Real Estate managing director, Jenny Lenz. Jenny and Dolly, it is good to see you both.

DOLLY LENZ, CO-FOUNDER, DOLLY LENZ REAL ESTATE: You too.

JENNY LENZ, MANAGING DIRECTOR, DOLLY LENZ REAL ESTATE: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Asses the market for us, what are you expecting this summer in real estate?

D. LENZ: Well, we're seeing a lot more inquiries, we're seeing lots of people at open houses, which is great, right? That starts the process. And we're seeing people happy that it's spring.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

D. LENZ: Right? They go outside, there's flowers blooming.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but you think the prices are going to come down?

D. LENZ: Yes. But it doesn't mean they're not going to take advantage of those prices coming down, right? Buyers will buy if they get a bargain. So they're looking for that bargain. Interest rates are so good now that anybody looking to buy is saving, what, 0.3 percent from just a month ago.

J. LENZ: And as sellers become more realistic, you know, we're going to see a lot more traction, a lot more buyers in the market. As she said, you know, spring is just the best time of year for New Yorkers. It really is a seasonal, somewhat of a seasonal market. No one wants to go see stuff in the winter, it's cold, everything looks terrible.

BARTIROMO: But what about the millionaire's tax? Let's get into the taxes that are -- that are taking effect.

D. LENZ: Not good -- not good. Millionaire's tax is really another trifecta problem, right? So, large supply of inventory, over-supply of inventory, lack of foreign buyers and now this tax, right? And plus the original tax, it's not good.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: The cap on state and local tax deductions.

D. LENZ: Exactly, right.

MCDOWELL: Deduction on the mortgage interest (INAUDIBLE)

D. LENZ: Which isn't even a cap, it's really a elimination, right?

MCDOWELL: Right.

D. LENZ: Because most people pay more than $10,000, so it is an elimination of real estate tax reductions.

MCDOWELL: The number transactions in Manhattan in the first quarter I read was the lowest in 10 years. So it is having -- people don't want to buy in high tax states for myriad reasons.

D. LENZ: Exactly, and we're also seeing the huge move down to places like Florida because it's not a -- you know, a tax state.

J. LENZ: Right, and ultimately, this will all be priced into condos in Manhattan, right? If you're going to make us pay higher taxes, we're not going to pay as much for an apartment. That's what we're seeing.

BARTIROMO: So, just to be clear, James, in California high earners are taxed 9.3 percent, plus an additional one percent surcharge on income over a million dollars. On the opposite coast, New York's upper cast taxed 8.82 percent on income over a million in 2018. And that's not including an additional millionaire's tax.

D. LENZ: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Yes, go ahead.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Or the New York city tax.

D. LENZ: Right.

FREEMAN: Wait a minute, we don't get the California weather either. So maybe there's not a good deal there. (INAUDIBLE) OK, so not a lot of buyers, prices lately not that firm. One, the people who are looking to buy, what are they looking for? Is it different from previous times?

D. LENZ: Well, they're looking for smaller, more efficient, newer homes and especially --

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X5P-D5S1-JDH1-C352-00000-00Tether, not Bitcoin, likely the world's most used cryptocurrency2019-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 0Tether, not Bitcoin, likely the world's most used cryptocurrencyOlga Kharif Bloomberg

What's the world's most widely used cryptocurrency? If you think it's Bitcoin, which accounts for about 70 per cent of all the digital-asset world's market value, you're probably wrong.

While concrete figures on trading volumes are hard to come by in this often murky corner of finance, data from CoinMarketCap.com show that the token with the highest daily and monthly trading volume is Tether, whose market capitalization is more than 30 times smaller. Tether's volume surpassed that of Bitcoin's for the first time in April and has consistently exceeded it since early August at about $21 billion per day (U.S.), the data provider says.

With Tether's monthly trading volume about 18 per cent higher than that of Bitcoin, it's arguably the most important coin in the crypto ecosystem. Tether's also one of the main reasons why regulators regard cryptocurrencies with a wary eye, and have put the brakes on crypto exchange-traded funds amid concern of market manipulation.

"If there is no Tether, we lose a massive amount of daily volume - around $1 billion or more depending on the data source," said Lex Sokolin, global financial technology co-head at ConsenSys, which offers blockchain technology. "Some of the concerning potential patters of trading in the market may start to fall away."

Tether is the world's most used stablecoin, a category of tokens that seek to avoid price fluctuations, often through pegs or reserves. It's also a pathway for most of the world's active traders into the crypto market. In countries like China, where crypto exchanges are banned, people can pay cash over the counter to get Tethers with few questions asked, according to Sokolin. From there, they can trade Tethers for Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, he said.

"For many people in Asia, they like the idea that it's this offshore, opaque thing out of reach of the U.S. government," said Jeremy Allaire, chief executive officer of Circle, which supports a rival stablecoin called USD Coin. "It's a feature, not a problem."

Tether, which is being sued by New York for allegedly commingling funds including reserves, says using a know-your-customer form and approval process is required to issue and redeem the coin.

Asian traders account for about 70 per cent of all crypto trading volume, according to Allaire, and Tether was used in 40 per cent and 80 per cent of all transactions on two of the world's top exchanges, Binance and Huobi, respectively, Coin Metrics said earlier this year.

Many people don't even know they use Tether, said Thaddeus Dryja, a research scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Because traditional financial institutions worry that they don't sniff out criminals and money launderers well enough, most crypto exchanges still don't have bank accounts and can't hold dollars on behalf of customers. So they use Tether as a substitute, Dryja said.

"I don't think people actually trust Tether - I think people use Tether without realizing that they are using it, and instead think they have actual dollars in a bank account somewhere," Dryja said. Some exchanges mislabel their pages, to convey the impression that customers are holding dollars instead of Tethers, he said.

The way Tether is managed and governed makes it a black box. While Bitcoin belongs to no one, Tether is issued by a Hong Kong-based private company whose proprietors also own the Bitfinex crypto exchange. The exact mechanism by which Tether's supply is increased and decreased is unclear. Exactly how much of the supply is covered by fiat reserves is in question, too, as Tether is not independently audited. In April, Tether disclosed that 74 per cent of the Tethers are covered by cash and short-term securities, while it previously said it had a 100 per cent reserve.

The disclosure was a part of an ongoing investigation into Tether by the New York Attorney General, which accused the companies behind the coin of a coverup to hide the loss of $850 million of comingled client and corporate funds.

John Griffin, a finance professor at the University of Texas at Austin, said that half of Bitcoin's runup in 2017 was the result of market manipulation using Tether. Last year Bloomberg reported that the U.S. Justice Department is investigating Tether's role in this market manipulation.

Convenience versus risk

"Being controlled by centralized parties defeats the entire original purpose of blockchain and decentralized cryptocurrencies," Griffin said. "By avoiding government powers, stablecoins place trust instead in the hands of big tech companies, who have mixed accountability. So while the idea is great in theory, in practice it is risky, open to abuse, and plagued by similar problems to traditional fiat currencies."

On the other hand, because Tether is key to their growth, many crypto exchanges would likely be willing to bail it out if needed, said Dan Raykhman, who is developing a platform for issuing digital assets and used to be head of trading technologies for Galaxy Digital.

"There's this implicit support from all these exchanges to help Tether stay afloat," he said.

While dozens of stablecoins have come out in the past year, many of them independently audited and regulated, Tether remains the favourite, by far.

"Tether has been around since 2014 - ancient antecedents in crypto - and has retained its value," said Aaron Brown, an investor and a writer for Bloomberg Opinion. "I don't say it's perfect, but its convenience outweighs its risk for many people."
